div.p: THE Careless Lovers: A COMEDY Acted at the Duke's THEATRE.
LONDON, Printed for William Cademan, at the Popes Head in the Lower Walk in the New Exchange, 1673.

div.head: THE EPISTLE To the READER.
div.p:
EPistles Dedicatory, and long Prefaces are of late much in Request; no Person of Quality, how remote soever, can escape the Impertinences of Poets; for though they be Hundreds of Miles off, they shall be pursu'd, and persecuted with Dedicatories o're and o're, even by the same Authors: which is a scurvy Compliment, like that of desiring a Man to be God-Father to every Child that is Born, though their Neighbours perhaps Club'd to the getting them; These Troubles, liberal Patrons, and kind God-Fathers, draw on themselves: But this is excusable in them that Write for Bread, and Live by Dedications, and Third-Dayes. If once in a Year they meet not with a good Audience, or a Bountiful Moecenas, we are to expect no Play from them the next; because they want Money to keep the great Wits company; from whose Conversation, once in Twelve Months, they pick up a Comedy. Yet this sort of Writers, or Wit-Collectors, are Bloodily angry, if you will not allow all the Wit in their Playes to be their own; and if they see another Man's Play take, Sware
and Bluster, and Bite their Nails; that you'd wonder how they do to Scratch their Heads, to bring forth the next: But I suppose their Nails soon grow agen, and so that's no great Harme. This sort of Men you shall hear say in the Pit, and at the Coffee-House (speaking of an Author) Dam me! How can he Write! He's a Raw Young Fellow, newly come from the University; How can he understand Humour or Character that is just come from a Colledge? Of another they Cry, S'death, he's no Scholler; he can't Write true Grammar: Then strutting, and looking Big; S'blood, sayes he, I understand Greek, as you may see by the Quotations in my Preface, and at the Front of my last New Play: But if they can neither Talk, nor Write a Young Poet out of the Humour of Making Playes, they give him o're for a peremptory Fop▪ and so fall to writing Siedges and Opera's—

But, Reader, lest by the ensuing Prologue, thou should'st think Me one of that Envious Tribe; know it was Written in Requital to the Prologue, before the Assignation, or Love in a Nunnery, and not without Provocation, Laesit prius: But Devils of Wit are not very dangerous, and so we both sleep in whole Skins.

If you are Inquisitive to know why there are such continual Picques amongst the Poets, I can give you no other Reason than what one Whore told the other— Two of a Trade can seldome agree— Now by way of Excuse for this Comedy, let me acquaint you, that it was written at the Desire of the Young Men of the Stage, and given them for a Lenten Play; they ask't it not above a Week before Shrove-Tuesday: In three dayes time, the Three first Act▪ were Made, Transcrib'd, and given them to write out in Parts— The Two last Acts, took me up just so much time▪ one Week compleated it. If this will not excuse it, Thou art as Uncons●onable and Malicious as the Writing Criticks, who say all they can for themselves, and will hear nothing in Defence of others. But I would not have Poets make this a President; for shortness of Time ought not to be pleaded in excuse of Ill Playes, unless on the like Occasion: For the Town I am sure will allow a Man ten Months, nay, ten Years, rather
than ten Dayes, if he will but bring a good One at last. I have much more to say, and as little to the Purpose, as any thing the best of my Fellow- Poets have said; but I'le consider on't a while, and some other time, when I have more Leisure, you shall have it; till then, Reader—

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: THey that observe the Humors of the Stage,
Find Fools and Heroes best do please this Age,
But both grown so extravagant, I scarce
Can tell, if Fool or Hero makes the better Farce:
As for Example, take our Mamamouchi,
And then Almansor, that so much did touch ye;
That Bully Hero, that did kill and slay,
And conquer ye Ten Armies in one day:
He that from side to side play'd Runnegade,
That Fought and Lov'd as if he had been mad.
He that gain'd Victory at ev'ry Stroke,
And made Kings tremble at each Word he spoke;
He that could Kill and Damne you with a Look.
Such are the Heroes, that with you are taking,
But such as never were of Heavens making:
Thus, whether Grave or Comick Scenes we write,
All's turn'd to Farce, by Hero, or by Knight.
Without one of these Two it is decree'd
By all of you, that no Play shall succeed.
An Author did to please you, let his Wit run
Of late, much on a Serving-Man and Cittern,
And yet you would not like the Cerenade,
Nay, and you Damn'd his Nun●s in Masquerade.
You did his Spanish Sing-Song too abhor,
Ayeque locura con tanto rigor.
In fine, the whole by you so much was blam'd,
To act their Parts, the Players were asham'd;
Ah! how severe your Malice was that Day,
To Damne at once, the Poet and his Play;
But why, was your Rage just at that time shown,
When what the Poet writ, was all his own?
Till then he borrow'd from Romance, and did Translate,
And those Playes found a more Indulgent Fate.
We fear you'l be incens'd again to day,
But consider, our's is a Lenten Play.
It was on purpose for the Young Men writ,
And all that's in it is Extempore Wit.
The Poet sayes, because he did not aime
At Credit, that he cannot meet with shame;
We Young-Men too, hope to be free from Blame;
For we do not design to please the Town
So much, as to get ev'ry Mans Half-crown:
And boldly we presume, that your Intent
Of coming now is for Encouragement.
Resolve then to be Kind to Us to Day,
And if You will, to Morrow, Damne the Play.

div.head: THE Careless Lovers.
The First Act, Scene First.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: COme back! Prithee Lovell, come back, and let's to the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Unconscionable Man! I tell thee I am going to see my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Pox o'thy Mistress; if thou wer't going to a Wench, I wou'd excuse thee; But I should think my self Damn'd, shou'd I consent to thy going to sollicit any Woman in the Way of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Wilt thou never leave this lewd wild Humour?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Not upon the score of Matrimony; Why, Iack Lovell, I'le tell thee I'am now like a Colt in the Fenns, that stragles every where, and feed where I like best: But shou'd I Marry, I shou'd be tether'd to my Spot of ground; at best, confin'd to an Inclosure.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But the Horse that is loose often falls into a foul Ditch; or is put in the Pound for ' straying into his Neighbours ground: Marriage is honest and safe.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p:
Yes; if all Wives were honest, I'le undertake a Miss shall love thee twice as long as any Wife thou can'st
find; nothing choaks Love like the Surety of Possession; Love is an excellent Meat, but Marriage is an ill Sauce; and believe me, it is the worst Estate of Mankind. If I was going to Tyburne, I wou'd cry, Drive on Carman; and choose to Sing my Penitential Psalme at the Gallows, rather than return to say, For Better for Wors●.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Atheists 〈◊〉 Love, ●●ke 〈◊〉 in Religion, are not to be reclaim'd by Argument; yet now and then are converted by some Accident or other. Thou may'st one Day see a Beauty, that like a Burning-Glass, shall draw all thy loose Flames within a narrow compass.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Beauty is mo●●●ittle than the Glass thou talk'st of; and Mans Estimation of it less Durable: I may perchance, Love only one at once; but not that one always: And whilst I am in my right Witts, I will not leave Delightful Variety for the Unsavoury Insipid Bitts of Constancy.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well; Iacinta, has a Kins-woman for her Companion, so Beautiful, her Eyes wou'd fix thy wandring● Thoughts, and make thee abandon all Women for her 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: So thinks the Devout young Novice newly enter'd into his Cloister; He has no sooner forsaken the World▪ the Flesh, and the Devil, but imagines he is able to perswade the greatest Debauchee, to make himself a Fool in the like manner.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I have not seen my Mistress these three Dayes; and my Mind is not compos'd enough, to return an Answer to every thing▪ You urge But venter thy Body within these Doors, and if ever thou return'st the same Man—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I know myself so well grounded in Sin, and have tasted so much the Sweets of Wickedness, that I dare venture my Self into any Temptations to the contrary: And for this once, I will suffer my self to be seduc'd by thee into Civil Company; And if they do debauch me—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come then—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But I know not how I shall forgive my self the Sin of forsaking Wine, Women, and Dice, for the Conversation of Damn'd Vertuous Women.

div.stage: Enter De Boastado and his Man, combing his Wigg, and adjusting his Garniture.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Careless, we are undone!

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: What Fantastick is this?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: It is the Vain, Idle, Simple, Conceited, Impertinent, Talking, Travelling Lord De Boastado (as he calls himself.)

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: He looks like a good Subject for Mirth, let's hear his Character more at large.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I ner'e saw him but twice in my Life; but once is enough to know what he is, for like a Word writ in Text, you may Read him all at first sight.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: So—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: He much values himself upon his Travelling; many Countries have taken Notice of him, and he of a few; he pass'd them o're as some Men do a great Library of Books; who Read the Title-page, then turn to Finis: He carry'd more Money out with him, than he brought Wit home: His Observations are of Modes, Fashions and Women: He speaks some few words in most Languages, but Sence in none: He has Baptiz'd himself with the Honourable Titles of most Countries: His Name is as long as a Coach and six Horses.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Let's fall upon him.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Shun him as you would the Plague.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Thou shalt stay, he makes full at us.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: He, he has prun'd himself, and comes with a full Swoop.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Mr. Lovell, good Morrow to you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Good morrow to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: What Gentleman is this?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A worthy Friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: One that has the Ill Fortune to be unknown to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p:
My Friend's Friend must not be a Stranger: I
am covetous of your better Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Pray do me the Honour to let me know to whom my Services are owing.

sp.speaker: De Boast.
sp.p: My Name is Mounsieur, Heiro, Signioro Countalto, Donno D'Boastado.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Bless me! De Boastado, what Arms bears that Family?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Sir, they are very famous, and thus blazon'd; but first imagine the Escutcheon in a Frame of beaten Gold, richly Enamell'd, set with Pearls, Rubies, Diamonds, and other precious Stones of great value and number, Incredible— for such an one have I hangs up in my Dining-Room against my Embroidr'd Hangings, that were presented me by the Emperour; betwixt a Golden Watch in a rich Case, given me by the King of Spaine, and a great Medal, with the Pope's Image on't: And underneath all this, hangs the Golden Armour I won in France, at the head of Four Thousand Men; I must confess there was not any one cou'd do the like, tho' they all try'd one by one— But no matter for that, let that pass.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I have heard much of your Fame, but as to your Heraldry.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You do well to put him in mind of his Text, for he was run too far from it, to come to't agen under the turning of an Hour-Glass.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.l: Well; now as to my Armes—
The Supporters of this Frame are
sp.p: The Griffin and Tyger Couchant, for on their two Backs it is borne up at each Corner: in the middle, by the Flower De less Crescent; on each side, guarded by the Dromadary and Elephant Rampant, which stand upon a Castle Guardant; on the Top of the Frame, is the Helmet Militant, held up in the Talet of an Eagle Volant, bearing a Crown upon her Head Triumphant.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: The Flourish of all Christendom!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: This is a strayn beyond what I ever heard yet.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: His Heraldry has run him out of breath.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p:
Then Gallants, in the Escutcheon, is only a Man
with a Spade Foclant in a Field Gules.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: A Silver Brim to a Wooden Dish.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Or a Leek Enchas'd in Gold.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: That wou'd be a fit Armes for him, for by the length of his Name, he shou'd be a Welch-man— But my Lord, these may be said the Armes of Adam.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: They are so; ours is a very Ancient Family, and we are lineally Descended from him— And our Motto is
sp.l: In Italian, Ciascunno è figliolo Del sue operè.
In English, Without Paines, no Gaines.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: We have trespass'd on you Lordship's Patience.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: We beg your Pardon, and take our leaves.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I hope your Friends better Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You honour me much.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: How far walk you this Way?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: No farther than this House.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Thither I am going too.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Are you acquainted with Mr. Muchworth.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: His Daughter will be a great Fortune, and I am in Treaty with him about a Marriage.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: About Marriage!

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Great Persons of mean Estates choose Wives out of the City; they are covetous of Honour, and we of Money. And here comes the Alderman.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Good morrow to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: D. Bost.
sp.p: How does your fair Daughter?

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: You honour me with enquiring after her— Oh Mr. Lovell, a word with you in private. Sir, you have for some time made Addresses to my Iacinta: But for the future, I desire you wou'd be a stranger to her— To me you shall be always welcome, but she is otherwise engaged?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: It is less in my Power not to love her, than to hate you; Tho' she shou'd follow your Example, and turn me off too.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: You know my mind, and shortly she'l let you know hers,— your Servant— My Lord, I'le wait you in— my Daughter and my Neece are but gone to buy a few Trifles at the Exchange; they'l be back soon.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Iacinta engag'd! false faithless Woman.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Prithee think no more of her. Come now, go with me and be merry; wee'l have Women in abundance.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hang e'm Jilts.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: No; such Women as your Mistress is, are more like Jilts. These are good Conscionable Girles, that will not let you spend your Money for nothing with the others; you waste your Gold and Time, and at last, like young Heifers when they come to be milk'd, they Spurn at you in Defiance, and away they frisk.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ah Iacinta! Hast thou forgot my Vowes? Unhappy Lover.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Damne this pineing, whineing, puleing, peaking, sneaking, sniveling Love: I'le carry thee where thou shalt see merry, gay, jocund, sprightly Love. Thou shalt have it in Arm-fulls, and Dilate thy self in Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: My Soul is out of Tune!

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Sir, Master, Sir, Madam Iacinta, and her Cousin Hilaria are just turn'd the Corner of this Street; I suppose they are coming home.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'le meet her, and tax her with her Inconstancy.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: They have both their Masques on, but you'l know e'm by Beatrice; my sweet Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: These are they. Lovell, accost thy own Natural, and leave me to manage the other Impertinent.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
My Heart's my Guide. Iacinta stay, stay Iacinta; Speak, tho' but one word, and tell me the Cause of this sudden
Alteration: Pull off your Masque, and let me see if your Face is alter'd as much as I hear your Heart is. Unkind Woman, dost thou flie me! I'le pursue thee as a Ghost does the guilty Murderer.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Now you and I, like Squire and Damsel, will follow Beatrice; if thou hast lost thy Tongue too, you and your Mistress are a Blessed pair; for were it not for your Tongues, you wou'd all be Angels.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Da, da, da—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Madam! You are not to pass so.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What wou'd the man be at?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: The Man's at what he wou'd be; he's at you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Faith I can't resolve you till I see your Face; pull off your Masque, and then I'le tell you what I mean.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Suppose I wont.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Nay, if you are good at Suppositions, suppose I am resolv'd to see it off.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Then I shou'd suppose you very Rude.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: And if you don't, I shall suppose you very Ugly; for I never knew a Woman that had a handsome Face cou'd endure to hide it.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yes, if she like not her Company.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yet, she'd have her Company like her; I trust more to a Woman's Pride, than her Love or good Nature: For tho' they are ugly, they think themselves handsome, and wou'd be thought so by others.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Why then do they maintain the Humour of Vizard-Masques?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Because under them they Sin conceal'd: I'le engage Vizard-Masques ruine more Womens Virtues than all the Bawds in Towne—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Your Reason for that.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p:
Under the Vizard the Wife goes to the Play, Ball, or Masquerade undiscover'd to her Husband; the Maid unknown to her Mistress; the Daughter or Neece unperceiv'd by her Relations:
The Masque invites the Gallants: And tho' at first you come but out of Curiosity, to hear what Men will say; Our Alamode Repertees, our Gentile Bawdry, and brisk Raillery tickles your Ears; your Bodies are buxome, your Bloods grow wanton, your Fancies strike firmly on some Man or oother; the Gallant grows Importunate, and you are Conquer'd.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Do you find Women then so fraile?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: A Womans Ear is the Out-work to her Chastity; get but there, and the Fort is more than half taken. When once a Woman hears what you say, she'l soon do what you'd have her.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Then you take a Parly for a Surrender.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: No, but after a Parly they soon yield.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Now have I a mind to stay and talk with you, but must be forc'd to leave you to avoid your ill Opinion.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Nay, if you have a mind to't you ' ido't; let me think what I will. And if you won't pull off your Masque, I'le e'en begone and leave you. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And fare you well.

div.stage: Turn from each others, and looks back o're their Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Nay, if you look o're Shoulder after me, I'le turn again, for you have no mind I should be gone I am sure.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Why did you look back at me?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: To see—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: If I wou'd look at you, and so we e'en caught one another; and what can you say to me of that which I can't Retort on you agen.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But I'le be judg'd by your self, if I have not more reason to think, you desire my stay, than I yours; You have a full sight of me, and see what I am, and now whether you like me or not: You are all Vizard, long Scarfe, and Petticoat; for ought I know, you may want a Nose, a Sett of Teeth, be Squint-ey'd, or Blobber lip'd.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: You'l make me as ugly as the Devil.
Am I not Cloven-footed think you?

div.stage: Offers to look on her Leggs.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I'le tell you that presently—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nay—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: A handsome Legg and a Foot I'le be sworn; and here's a well shap'd Hand and Arme; and what Breasts are here? How round and plump?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Hands off, your enquiry begins to grow troublesome.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: If you have a Face and Features answerable to your Limbs, you'r a prime piece of Womans Flesh.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Do you think I have?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Gad do I.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Then to keep you in your good Opinion, I'le begone, and you shan't see't: Nay, nay, no Attempts, hands off.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I have sworn to see't.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And I have sworn you shall; but stand at greater Distance: Farther, farther yet— See

div.stage: Hil. gets her back close to her Uncles Door, pulls off her Masque, steps in, and shuts it.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Excellent Creature!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Ha! are you so cunning? She has lock'd the Door against me.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: My Master, Sir, is gone out the Back-way, and sent me to give you Notice.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I'le be with him presently.

By her Witt, I did not judge she had so good a Face; for Wit and Beauty seldome go together in a Woman: She has a large stock of both, and I cou'd wish my self in Bed with her: but the Thoughts of her are Momentary.
sp.l: I'le keep my Soul free as the Bird that flyes i'th Aire,
I'le ne'r love one, till I of all besides Despair.

div.head: The Second Act.
div.stage: Enter Lovell and Toby, Beatrice meeting e'm.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: MOst luckily met, I am sent Embassadress of good News, and was just coming—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Return, and Attempt not to deceive me with fair Words. Return, I bid thee, and tell thy Faithless Mistress her Unhappy Lover will not long be the subject of her Scorne: Bid her practice her Receipt elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: My sweet Face, tell me, What Humor is this has possess't thy Master?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Your sweet Face, you Impertinent: Go, do as you'r bidden, Be gone, go.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Hey! Are you in the same Tone?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Be gone Baggage: Speak not a Word more for your Life.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What a Vengeance ayles you both? Well, I'le go informe my Mistress how Squares go.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Thus to treat a Lover, and one that was the most passionate, and most faithful of all Lovers.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Tis strange to me they should treat us so.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I have show'd the greatest Love and Tenderness for her that can be imagin'd; I lov'd Nothing in the World but her; Thought of Nothing but her; and Sleeping, dream't of Nothing but her: She was all my Desire, all my Joy; I spoke not of anything but her: And is such a Love thus Rewarded! These three Dayes I have not seen her, seem'd so many Ages for me: And am I in three Dayes forsaken and forgotten? I meet her, and she will not speak to me, not look at me; but shun me as a Thing she hates.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ah Sir, I may say the same, for Beatrice will follow her Mistress; Honey or T— as she is.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Can Iacinta be match'd for Ingratitude?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Or that Baggage Beatrice?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: To forsake me after so many Sighs and Vows which I have offer'd to her Charmes.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: To leave me after so many good Offices and daily Services I have done for Her.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: After so many Tears shed at her Feet.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: After so many Payles of Water lugg'd up Stairs for her, to wash her Roomes.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: After I had express'd so Ardent an Affection, and so gen'rous a Flame for her.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: After I have so often kindl'd a Fire for her in her Mistress Chamber, and Scortch'd my self with taking her Heaters for her out of the Fire.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Does she after all this, refuse to speak to Me?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Does she for all this turn Cat in Pan?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And flie from my sight.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: And turn her Back-side with a Pox to me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Her Unkindness deserves my severest Resentments.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Her Pettishness merits a hundred Kicks i'th Breech.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I charge thee never speak to me of her, nor for her.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I, Sir! not I by Grandsires Beard.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Never attempt to excuse her Infiedlity.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Never fear't.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'le be Deaf to all you can say in her behalf.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I think not any thing of't.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I will cherish my Anger, and break off all Intimacy with her.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Agreed: And I'le break off my Intreigue.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Perhaps she's taken with this Foolish Lord, and puff'd up with Hopes of being a Lady— Ambition is the Vice of her Sex; but she shall not boast an absolute Glory; for I'le Abandon her as she does me.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I much approve your Resolution.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
Do thou lend it Aide against all that Love can urge to
the Contrary; I conjure thee, find all the Faults in her thou can'st, and Lampoon her to me in a Description—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Shaw waugh;— You may find a thousand prettier Women than she. In the first place, her Hair inclines to Yellow.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That's but the Lustr'e of her Hair.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Her Forehead's low.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But smooth and Delicate.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Her Nose is too bigg.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But well shap'd.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: When she speaks, she draws her Mouth from Ear to Ear.—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Which discovers such a fine Sett of Teeth, so white and even; and her Lipps so red.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: And keeps her Teeth close, which makes such a Jarring in her Speech.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That breaks the fulness of the Voyce, and makes a pretty kind of Harmony.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Her Face is a White clumsey big-face.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But every Feature is so excellent, the greatest Crittick in Beauty knows not where to take away, or what to add.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Then she has a peaking way of holding down her Head.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But at the same time, appear such a pattern of Modesty and Innocence.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Her Breasts are too bigg.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But are firm and white, and such delicate blew Veyns, Their Bigness seems Graceful.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: She's Lanck Buttock'd.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Finely turn'd about the Hipps.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Her Stature is low.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Aug●●l of a fine middle Size; not so Tall to or'e, ●●p a Man, nor so Low as to be or'e-look'd.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: She's of too dull and serious a Humour.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That which you call Dulness, is her Modesty; and her Seriousness, is the Effect of her Sage discreet Behaviour.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: But she's very pettish—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
Which shews she has a Spirit. But in the Fair nothing
seems amiss, and in them we easily pass o're small Faults.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Lord Sir! She's a Book without an Errata; never did such a perfect Impression come from the Press of Nature: I see how things will go. Whom we excuse, we Love—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Love her! I'le rather Die. I'le more disesteem her than ever I priz'd her.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: This is not the right course you take.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: In this my Revenge will shew it self; the more full of Charms she appears, the more Glorious will the Conquest be: When from my Heart, I drive the Sentiments of Love, and plant in their Room, Contempt and Disdaine.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Here she comes; now stand your Ground.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: His behaviour Madam was such, I have nothing to say in his Excuse.

sp.speaker: Iacin.
sp.p: He's here.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'le not so much as speak to her.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I'le follow your Example.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: What makes you so strange?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Why stand you at so great a Distance?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: What distrubs your Mind?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What a murren ailes you?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Perfidious Woman.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Hah! Mrs. Iudas.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I see my Company is troublesome to you; was my Silence this Morning the ground of your Anger?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Let me tell you, you shall not Triumph in your Infidelity; I will banish the Love I have for you from my Heart, and leave in it no Impression your Eyes have made.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: No nor I neither.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I will acquaint you with the Cause why I held not discourse with you this Morning.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'le hear nothing.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I'le tell you why we were Mu●.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I am deaf.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: My Father— Lov. I care not.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: My Mistress— Tob. My Master.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Hear me!— Lov. No.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Hark you—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: No, hark you—

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Mr. Lovell—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Mrs. Iacinta.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Dear Toby—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Sweet Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Stay.—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Come back—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I won't.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Pray hear me—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Excuse me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: One word—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Not a Syllable.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: You'l begon—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: You wont stay—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Well, since you will not hear me speak, Remain in your Ignorance, and do as you please.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Since you are so frumpish, a Pin for you.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: And a Fart for you Mrs. Turd-pie.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well then, say what you wou'd say.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: My Mind is alter'd now.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Come tell your Tale.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: No matter now.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What was it?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Begin.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I have done.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Pray speak.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Excuse me.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Come out with it.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I entreat.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: In vain.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I petition.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: To no purpose.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I conjure you.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Pray go.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: In the name of Iupiter Speak—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Be gone.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Iacinta.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Lovell.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Toby.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You'r resolved.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: You'l be obstinate.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Lay aside your Anger.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Let your Gizzard leave grumbling.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I'le have nothing to do with you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Since you are so Averse, to let me know the Cause why you treated me so Ill, and prov'd so false to your Faith, This is the last time you shall ever see me, for I will turn Wanderer, and spend my dayes in Travel.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ay, and so will I.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: But Lovell.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: But Toby.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: ‛ Say you.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: What are your Intentions?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: To banish my self from my Country.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: To turn Vagabond.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: You must not go.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Your Unkindness drives me hence.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: You shan't be gone.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: You'r grown so Turdy the Devil wou'd not endure your Company.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Lovell, 'tis you are unkind, to condemn me unheard.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You refus'd to speak for your self.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: It was not then convenient: My Father both this Morning, and e're since I saw you last, charg'd me never to admit you more in Conversation, nor to see you; cou'd I help it? And sayes his Curses shall be my Portion, if I disobey him.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Will you be so unjust?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Never; tho' you shou'd prove so to me!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: By your Father's words, I understood you were as willing to retreat from my Love, as he to have you—

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I saw, e're since that Foppish Lord made his Pretentions to me, that my Father was resolv'd to put a Stop to our Proceedings. I seemingly comply'd— for had I urg'd his Anger with my Denyals, he wou'd not only have banish'd you from his house, but have, Immur'd me in my Chamber, till I had been dispos'd of; Then I should have lost the satisfaction of seeing you, which I now may have if things be manag'd discreetly.—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You acted prudently—

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I durst not speak to you this Morning: when I return'd,
I spy'd my Father at the Window.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Look you now, the Secret is out.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: 'Twas e'en so, I verily believe.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ah Iacinta! See what pow'r you have or'e me, that can with one word appease all the Mutinies in my Mind: and with what Facility, we let our selves be perswaded by them we love.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ah these White Devils have as great power over their Servants, as the Black Devil over Sinners.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Madam, the Door begins to open.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Begone Sir. I fear it is my Father.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Adieu—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: You have a happy time on't Cozen, you are alwayes merry!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I vow Coz. I have so laugh'd at his Lordship.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: How can'st thou laugh at such a Fool?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: He's one of the most pleasant Comedies Nature ever brought into the World.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: He's but a meer Farce!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: His Taylor is come after him with a New Suit, but of the oddest Fashion— he is putting it on, and will soon be here to shew it you; he sayes 'tis of his own Invention.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I wish thee in my place; you wou'd know how to mannage him.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I wou'd my Uncle had ordain'd him for my Lover.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: And do you wish he were to be your Husband too?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: There's a certain Reason, Madam, why a woman shou'd wish to have a Fool for her Husband.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yes Beatrice, but I do'nt; he's not Fool enough for that!

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: For my part I believe it to be a Vulgar Error.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Some are so skilful, as to judge of those matters from the Features; but Experience is the best Mistress.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Ay Madam!— from thence comes the most certain Knowledg.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: You talk so I don't know what you mean.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Alas poor Innocent!

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Why Madam, we may talk or mean what we will; we are alone.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I blush at your Answer.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Dear Coz, you are a very Wag at your heart, or you'd not blush at what she said.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Here comes your Animal.

div.stage: Enter De Boastado in his New Suit, and a Taylor.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Never let me have your Custome, if it be not exactly to your Description!

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I think it is; Madam Iacinta, I come to shew you my Gallantry. 'Tis an odd Fancy, but new; 'Tis my own Invention. How does it please you?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Wonderfully well.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It is well quarter'd.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: We want a Herald to blazon it.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I never lik'd Suit better.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I am glad you all like it, for I wou'd not let my Taylor go, till I had got your Approbation. Hark you! How many Artists sat in Consultation about it?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: According to your Lordships Appointment, Twelve.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: A Jury of Taylors to make up one Fool.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: How make you up the Number?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Four French Taylors.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Why four French?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Because they are the best Mathematicians at Cutting out. Go on—

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Three Spanish.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Why Spanish?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Auh! Their deliberation in proceeding does much. They set not a Stich without Thought, and their Gravity is a good Allay for the French Mercury. It gives Fixation to their volatile Spirits. Proceed—

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Two Italians, one German, and one Polander.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: And why those my Lord?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p:
Because I pass'd through their Countries in my
Travels, and have here something of the best of all their Garbs.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: In this Suit Ladies, you may read all the Countries of my Travels; I design'd it on purpose, to give the World Intelligence where I have been.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I vow 'twas a pretty Contrivance—

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Yes very Ingenious—

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: And to make the Number, the Twelfth was an Englishman, and that my self.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Go thy ways, and carry thy Bill to my Steward, and bid him pay thee thy Money.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I thank your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Now do I wish to be well quit of him.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Go you in, and I'le endeavour to detain him.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Going away, 'tis Unkind not to take me with you.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I am going about a small Affair my Maid tells me of.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Accept of my Company till she returns.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Oh Madam, 'Tis most agreeable.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I wou'd it were my Lord.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Why sigh you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Wou'd I was as handsome as my Cozen.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: You are, Lady.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And as good a Fortune too.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Your Fortune is large, your Uncle tells me.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But not answerable to hers. I wou'd it was.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Repine not Fair one.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Hi ho!

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Pray why sigh you so?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I wish my Lord.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: What pretty one?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: That you had never seen my Cozen.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Because I think she'● love you—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: And I'le love her—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But I wish you'd love some body else.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: And why do you wish it?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Because a Friend of mine loves you.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: You mock me. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: No my Lord, 'tis too true— That you may know I do not, I cou'd tell you of more than one that loves you passionately.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I must confess it has been my Fortune to be belov'd by considerable Persons, in all places where-ever I have travell'd— At Rome the Pope's Neice fell in Love with me, and sent me her Picture richly set in Jewels. In Tuscany the Grand Duke's Sister. I cou'd tell you something of an Intrigue with the Sultana, when I was at Constantinople, but it is something incredible.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nay, I have reason to believe it, for no Woman sees you without some concern; even in this very Street lyes a young Lady that has Forty thousand Pounds to her Portion, and she but saw you pass along the Street once or twice, as you came hither, and is falne in Love with you: And hearing of your pretensions here, is since falne sick, and has kept her Bed these two ' dayes.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I protest I am sorry; but is she so great a Fortune.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: My Uncle knows her, and all her Concerns as to those things.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Humh—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I cou'd tell you of some body else too. But 'tis not convenient.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: That's her self— this may be worth enquiry.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lawyer's within; if you please, we will look o're some Particulars of your Estate, that we may forward the Settlement of a Joynter for my Daughter.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p:
I have some reason to think, she and I may not
disagree. Your Servant Lady.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I had not return'd to you, but that I saw my Father come this way.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You miss'd the Relation of his forreign Amours: But I have perswaded his Lordship, that you and I are in love with him, and that a great Fortune has kept her Bed this two dayes, hearing he pretends to you—

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: And is sick for love of him.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yes! he believes it.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: He's a most credulous Coxcomb— But should he find you out to be a Lyar.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Not a greater than himself, he cannot I am sure!

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: How can'st thou in Conscience make such a Fool of him.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Heav'n ordain'd every thing for some use or another; and he can serve for no other than our Pastime.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Ha! these are they!

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Here comes Mr. Lovell's Friend.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Now which of e'm is she that I am in love with?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: He's at a stand.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: He'd fain know me agen; but prithee take up a Brisk Humor, and let's try to puzzle him.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: No! Prithee let's go in.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: What, are you upon this Wing? Do you come out a Grazing like Rabbets just at the Burrows mouth; that as soon as any body comes, you may pop into your Holes agen.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: We had need be watchful; when such Pochers as you are abroad.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Your watchfulness signifies little: I come now like a Ferret to creep into your Holes, and scare you out of your Burrows.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: But if instead of a Burrow, you shou'd run into a Warreners Trap.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And that you may easily do; for we are no Out-lying. Conies, we keep within Heart of the Warren.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I, but I know your Musees, your In-lets, and Out-lets, and where-ever the Rabbets pass, the Ferret or Weezel may venture. You see I come just to the same place; 'twas here you pop't in from me before; but now I am got between you and the Hedge.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: But how do you know that we are the same Pair?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And which of us is it that was too nimble for you?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: You had best have a care on which you adventure, for in such cases, you ought not to spoyl your Friend's Game.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: 'Tis one of you!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I see you are no good Hound. You can't follow the Scent well.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Many a good-Nos'd Dog is at a loss when Scent is cross'd; but if I catch one, and my Friend another, if we are mistaken, let him say which is his, and wee'l make a change.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: But which of us two, do you think, wou'd fall to your share.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I' Gad I do'nt know.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Do'nt you know a woman's Face when you see't a second time—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: She show'd it with-such a Leger-De-Maine; her Masque was no sooner off, than on agen; and she was gone.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Observe us well.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Let me see— Faith not I— If you had your Masques on, I should know her from a thousand, at the very sight of her Vizard, my Heart wou'd go Pitty-pat.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: If you are so in Love with the complexion of Velvet, you shou'd have a Nigra for your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: There is Beauty in Black; Why else do Ladies put 〈◊〉 Patches? And some love Black-hair better than Light, and 〈◊〉 why not Black faces as well.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: But you'd be for a White one at this time, if you knew but which was under the Vizard.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: 'Tis well for us he does not, for then he'd pretend Love to one of us.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Gad but I wou'd not to you, nor ne'r a Woman in the World.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I dare swear you wou'd.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Perhaps I might make you believe I was in Love with you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: No, that you cou'd ne're do.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Why, don't you think your selves handsome enough to be lov'd?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Yes; but we think you have more Wit..

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: What, then to love one of you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yes, or any body else that is never like to love you agen.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Are you an Enemy to me or to Love?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: To love. I think it is a very foolish thing.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But 'tis Marriage makes it so. Give me Love as Nature made it, Free and Unconfin'd.— Observe but Mistress, and Gallant: How Brisk, how Gay, how Fierce they are in their Amours! Whil'st Marriage-love comes like a Slave loaden with Fetters, dull and out of humour.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: For my part, I am rather for a Gallant than a Husband.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: So am I clearly—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: 'Tis well dissembl'd on one side; one of you I am sure speaks against her Conscience, but if you are as you say, you'r Girles for me.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: What both?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Both, ' I gad both—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Hold, one's enough; and if you'l be a Gallant to one of us, we expect you shou'd be constant.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: That Circumstance makes it too like Marriage.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: The Constancy is while you pretend; not but that either Mistress or Gallant may choose elsewhere, but they must love but one at once.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: But which of us will you choose?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Faith I'le be for her I talk'd to in the Masque.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Madam! Dinner's on the Table.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Already.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: My Master has call'd for't, he's in haste to go out.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: We come: Well Sir, when you find which of us two is she; claim her for your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Adien.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Come Hilaria.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Ha! Hilaria, i'faith, that's she. But they are gone. Iacinta I remember, is the Name of Lovell's Mistress, till now I fancy'd the other was she, because she was more brisk and airy. Well, I'le find out my Friend, and we'l give a visit in the Afternoon.
sp.l: If for a Wife my Liberty I loose,
One of these Two shou'd catch me in a Noose.

div.head: The Third Act.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: YOur Joynture is agreed on; and Directions are given for the Drawing of the Writings; therefore put things in readiness, and dispose your self for Marriage; for it must be within a day or two.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Sure Sir, if you lov'd me, you'd not be so hasty to be rid of me.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p:
It is the great Care and Love I have for thee, makes
me solicitous to see thee well-dispos'd. My Lord is a Person of Worth and Honour, and thou wilt be happy in his Love; Iacinta thou'lt be a Lady—

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: My Lord merits, I question not, a Wife much above me in Desert; But how do you think I can on the sudden, resolve to leave the Family of him that got me, bred me, and brought me up to what I am.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Your Mother did the same before You; and for this thou hast had all thy Education: This is the last great Act a Father can do for his Child; in this his Care ends, and when we give a Daughter in Marriage, 'tis suppos'd, we give her to more than a Father, for such is a Husband; Husband and Wife are one.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: That rule Uncle, won't hold in Arithmetick, for according to the first principle, one and one make two.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Mad-cap Neice, meddle with your own matters. Let me see—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nay Uncle, ner'e put on your Considering-Cap, for an Answer. What I say is true; and I'le give you a further Demonstration, that Man and Wife are not one: For in this Age they are seldom, or never together; the Man's in one place, and the Wise in another▪ as far asunder as ever they can get. And you know it is impossible for one and the same thing to be at the same time in several places.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: She has a very unhappy Wit. I am glad, Daughter, that you are going from her, for she's enough to spoil all the Young Women she meets with; but I hope she'l have a Husband will meet with her.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Never of your Choosing, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Likely so, for you'r Hair-brain'd enough, to do things of your own Head. But your Father when he Dy'd, left you to my Care, and bid that you shou'd be Rul'd by me; and if you are not, your Disobedience will come home to you one day or other.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: This is but talk. Do you think, Uncle, I han't as much Wit to choose a Husband as you?

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p:
Well, well, follow your own Course; but I hope
you'l get a Husband one day will Cudgel your Bones for you.—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But Uncle, it is not now as it was in your young dayes, Women then were poor sneaking sleepish Creatures. But in this Age, we know our own strength, and have wit enough to make use of our Talents. If I meet with a Husband makes my Heart ake, I'le make his Head ake I'le warrant him.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Nay, I am apt enough to believe one house will be too not to hold you long. I doubt not but your Husband (who e're has the ill fortune to be so) will in a short time be as weary of you as I am.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: If he shou'd prove but half so ill-natur'd as you are (which certainly no Young Man can) I'd swear my self a Virgin, and consequently, Sue a Divorce against him for Impotency.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: I must be gone, this Wench will never hold her prattle; she'd out-talk e'm at a Bake-house.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Well, thou'rt a mad Wench to talk so.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Pish! I'le have Women say and do what they will: Have not we Rational Souls as well as Men; what made Women Mopes in former Ages, but being rul'd by a company of old Men and Women: Dotage then was counted Wisdom, and formerly call'd Gravity and good Behaviour.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: What can'st thou advise me to in this extremity. I hate this Foolish Lord.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Let him know your Mind, and if he won't believe you, tell him he's an Unmannerly Fool.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: If I break with him, my Father will conclude I affect Mr. Lovell, and to cross me, never consent I shou'd have him; And he's the only Man I can Love.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: See! he's here, and our Gallant with him; wee'l con-spute the Bu'sness with them.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Mr. Lovell, how durst you venture here.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
This Gentleman told me your Father was to go abroad
this Afternoon; and by his perswasion and my own Inclinations, we adventur'd to wait on you, and just as we came into the Street, my Lord and he pass'd by us in a Coach.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And who sent for you Gallant?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I hope, Madam, you'l allow a man to look after his Heart when 'tis gone a'stray.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You cou'd not find it the last time you were here.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You conspir'd to juggle me on't; but I know well enough which of you had it.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: You are beholding to Mr. Lovell for your Knowledg.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, Madam, upon my word, but he has told me his Adventures.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Well, Madam; I hope you'l stand to your Bargain.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: We are no Flinchers; wee'l not be worse than our words.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Well then, you I challenge for my Mistress; you were the Lady I talk'd to in the Masque.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I am not her I'le assure you—

div.stage: Carel. takes Jac. by the hand.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I am well assur'd it cou'd be none but you; I knew it when I was here before, tho' I did not then own it.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Take nay word Sir.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Lord that you shou'd think to deceive me; why all the while I was in the Company before, my Heart beat all on that side you stood, and my Cheek next you burnt and glo'de.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, 'slife he has not found it out yet.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, I'le be swore Careless han't you.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I'le be sworn Madam, Hilaria was the Person.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha: But that's my Cozen Iacinta.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: No, no, no, did not you call her Hilaria as you went in.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I thought how well you know; and did that on purpose to try you—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Ba—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Now Careless thou art caught—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: What wou'd I give now to come handsomely off: I must be impudent: Well, Madam, to let you see that I did, go both of you out of the Room, and come in Masqu'd, and if I don't choose the Right, I'le be content to resigne the Hopes of a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: There is but right and wrong.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: To give you a greater Proof on't, I'le make my choice Blind-fold.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: 'Twill still be an even Wager that you hit on the right.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Careless, thou art Out-witted i'faith.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Servant, our Covenant is voyd for Non-performance of the Conditions.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But calling of me Servant after the Condition is broken, is a Confirmation— and will make it stand good in Law.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No Careless, that Quirk won't do neither.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But Madam, I hope you'l give a man leave to retreat, when he finds his Errour; your self occasion'd the Mistake, 'twas an Errour of my Hand, not of my Heart, for at the same time, I told you Hilaria was she, and you are Hilaria; Therefore 'twas you I meant.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yes, yes, 'twas me you meant; when your Cheek glo'd, and your Heart beat on the left side!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Cozen, you are too great a Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You pursue your Victory too severely; 'tis generous to give the Vanquish'd quarter.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I do more; I give him Liberty to make his retreat.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Ah Madam, your Father has met with his Lawyers
Clark, who told him his Master was not at home, and he's return'd already.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Convey Mr. Lovell out quickly Sir; will you go with him?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: 'Tis not possible, Madam, he's just coming into the Room.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Ha! Mr. Lovell— Daughter, I see you observe my Commands well: Sir, I beseech you; What makes you here?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir, I come to wait on my Friend.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yes Sir▪ I had much adoe to perswade him; but considering the bus'ness I came about, requir'd some Body to give you an Account of me, which none cou'd do better than he; he did adventure to trespass on you to serve me.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: What Bus'ness, pray Sir!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ay, what indeed?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: It was my Fortune twice or thrice, to have a sight of your fair Niece, as she went abroad.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Sure he's not so mad to tell him.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: To whom, Sir, I took so great a liking, that Day nor Night, I cou'd not rest, till I had found who she was, and where she liv'd; which I had no sooner done, but engag'd him to come along with me, to acquaint you who I am, and what my Fortunes are, hoping to gain your leave, to make my Addresses to this fair Lady—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: This I hope Sir, will gain me your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Do you, Sir, know this Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes, his Name is Careless; I believe, Sir, you might know his Father.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: I did so, he was a worthy Gentleman; 'tis now some eight years since he dy'd.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: 'Tis so long; peace be with him.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: He left some Twelve hundred a Year to his Son, then not at Age.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: This Gentleman is that Son.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: But has he that Estate?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Every Acre, Sir.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: I heard you were a little wild.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I have my Froliques as most young Men have— but I keep my Estate out of the Devil's Clutches; I have yet not sold one Foot of Land, or cut down one Stick of Wood.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Nay Sir, if you were as wild as wild could be, you'd meet with your Match there, my Niece is as wild as you can be, she's Vain, Idle, Careless, and Talkative.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Uncle, you shou'd do in driving Bargains for Marriage as they do in Selling of Horses; tell their good Qualities, and leave it to 'em to find out the ill.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: These are Faults will be discover'd in you at first sight.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sir, I hope you'l like me ne're the worse for what he sayes.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Instead of his getting you for a Wise, you intend to get him for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It is more to the humour of the Age; if you won't commend me, I'le commend my self; and if I thought but half so well of him as Id 'of my self, wee'd soon shake hands for to have and to hold without your leave.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: You see her humour Sir, if after this you dare venture on her, I shall not counsel her against you; provided what Mr. Lovel and your self say be confirm'd by good Authors; for I wish her well Marry'd.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Stay Uncle, now I think on't, you may take him with you. Marriage is quite out of Fashion, and I hate to be out of it, as much as you do to be in't; if he had Ten or Twelve Thousand a year, would keep me a Coach and six Horses, and all things suitable to that Grandeu●r, I might admit him as a Gallant, and all that—

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: I'le leave you to her; at this mad rate she talks all the Year round.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I did not think Careless, thou had'st had a Lye so much at command.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: It was to serve my Friend and these Ladies.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But the Jest wou'd be, if your Lye should prove true, and you shou'd play such a Simple trick, as to fall in L'ove with me indeed and indeed.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Make your own words true, and accept me for a Gallant, I know not what may follow—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But you know what you must have first— A huge Estate; but because you brought us so handsomely off? There's my Hand to Kiss, and I confer on you the Title of my Servant.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: He cur'd a present Evil. I wish he cou'd as easily divert what I fear will follow.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Madam, we must court Fortune as we do a Mistress; never leave her when she's in a good humor. Let's hear your Grievance:

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: 'Tis the Match my Father drives on so eagerly with that Lord.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Will he not be satisfi'd, if you tell him you can't love him.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Hee'l not take that Answer from her, nor ne'r a Woman alive.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: He thinks we are both in love with him.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Since Dinner I writ a Love-Letter to him; I have made him believe too, that the Rich Heiress that lodges in this street languishes for him.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: And he pitties her extreamly.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Hark you Lovel; Let's put him upon courting this Great Fortune.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But it may be he'l not quit his hold here.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: For so great an Advantage he may: And it must be your parts, Ladies, to give him sufficient grounds to conclude, that neither of you love him.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Let us alone to give him proof of that.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Then we will contrive to bring him in Disgrace with your Father. Lady of the Bed-chamber, you must act a part in our Comedy, attend us to the Door; you shall receive Instructions as we goe.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Here's my Father; let us retreat and consult about our Affairs.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: You know this Lady I suppose.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: I have seen her: But I am very well acquainted with her Uncle.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: And has she so great a Fortune?

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Yes, it lies in the three Banquers hands we were but now speaking of.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I'know it does; for when I parted with you, I made enquiry, and they confirm'd it: She lodges in the middle of this street. Mrs. Rich is her Name.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Right: But my Lord, do you think she has so great a Kindness for you?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I speak not without good Reason; and were I not Engag'd by Love and Honour to your Daughter, I wou'd make an Attempt.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Her Uncle trusts her not out of his sight.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I cou'd find ways to speak to her, but I prize Mrs. Iacinta above all Women. Tho' there are others have no small Kindness for my Person, and one you know took but she shall be nameless; yet I'le shew you what a passionate● Letter she sent me. You shall hear it.

sp.speaker: Reads.
sp.p: My Lord:

Your Person is so Taking, and your Obligements so conquering, that no Woman living, and you beholding, can resist Loving: Therefore since of this you are knowing; I doubt not your pardoning her, that with Blushing tells you her Ailing; the Ioy of whose being, is, when you and she is seeing: Your's remaining for Everlasting.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: This is a very Odd strayne.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Ah, 'tis very Amorous, and I pitty the Lady for your sake.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Is she Related to me!

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: The first Letter of her Name is Hilaria.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p:
My Niece, this is some Trick of hers; but I dare not
tell him he's abus'd, lest he should take it ill, and think my Daughter had a hand in't— But of all that love you, your Lordship can have but one.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: True; yet 'twou'd vex a Man to Discard Trumps, but 'tis a forc't Put: This I tell you, to give you a Proof of my Love for your Daughter. I know poor Thing she loves Me.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: My Lord! You'r a happy Man, we have over heard your Amours.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I did not think you had been so nigh.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Without Doubt, you were wrapt in your Mothers Smock.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Hey— Ho!

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Observe that Sigh, and how she eyes me. Lady you'r Melancholy.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You call'd my Thoughts from a pleasing Contemplation.
I was thinking—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Of what Madam?—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Of you my Lord.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I saw you look wishly on Me.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I was thinking what good Eyes your Lordship has.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: O fine Eyes! if they stood but more out, and were not sunck in's head, like Candle-Snuffs in their Sockets.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And did not squint so much.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Mine, mine Ladies.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Why Baggages.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: He has a handsome Nose too.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Was it not an Inch too short.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: And turn'd up at the end with the Air of a French Dog.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Why Girls, what mean you?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Pretty good Cheeks— Were they not so lean and pale!

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: And fal'n in for want of Side-Teeth.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: The Devil's in e'm both.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: A handsome Mouth were it not so wide.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And his Lips not so Thin and Blewish—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I am abus'd.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Have done, or I'le lay my Staff about your ears.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: His Gums not so worn away.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And his Teeth not so rotten.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: His Mouth not so furr'd.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: His Breath not so scented with the French Hogo.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Disgrace to my Dignity.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: They are Mad, Distracted. They know not what they doe.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: He's Leather-jaw'd— Chap-falne.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: And has a Swarthy, Tawny, Tallow Complexion.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Peace, and have done in the Devil's name.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: In fine, was your Lordship but ten times as handsom, you'd be a pretty well-favour'd Man.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And fit to be lov'd by a Woman of Sixty and upwards.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Intolerable, insufferable, insupportable!

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Ho! Within there!

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: You Huswifes you, say you are Mad, say you are Drunk, or any thing; or I'le swinge you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: No, no, Uncle; We are neither mad nor drunk.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Husie; your Reason for this.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Why does he make his Brags that we are in Love with him, and so fond of his Company?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: We have given him Proofs of our Kindness. In Love with him!

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Get you up to your Chambers; Go! Husbands;
Halters you deserve—
Have Patience, be pacified, the Baggages shall down on their knees to you.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! This is only to blind you. Ha, ha, ha, 'Twas your Nieces Frolick; they love me as they love their own eyes— and because I told you on't— Ha, ha, ha— See what tricks they play to cozen you, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: I'le instantly know the truth on't, or—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Henceforward, I will hate their whole Sex for their sakes, I will defame the Living, revile the Dead, and leave a Curse to the Generation of Females to come.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lord—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Avoid thou She-Devil; thou art a Satan in Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Ah my Lord; if you knew my Errand, you'd say I was an Angel; I have such News for your Lordship.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: News! What is't?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: If a Woman might but trust your Lordship with her Secrets.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I hope she's in love with me; she's a Bit will serve to stay a mans stomach when he's hungry. What Secrets Pretty Beatrice? Dost thou love me?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Ah dearly, dearly, my Lord— But—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: But you are asham'd to tell me your mind.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I am afraid—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Thou should'st have a great Belly—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: No, my Lord, that you shou'd tell—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: No: I'le tell no body; go, go up to your Chamber, and I'le steal after you—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: No my Lord, I can do the Business here—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Art thou a Virgin?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: As to Deeds a very Innocent; but in Words and Thoughts, I have been a little waggish.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Come into the next Room.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: No, no, I am only to tell you—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: No matter for telling, we will talk afterwards,

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: See this Gold, my Lord here are Twenty pieces.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: And you wou'd have as much more.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I shall deserve it.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Wilt thou go then, go.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: This Gold my Lord was given me.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: For that, that thou hast more mind I should have.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: No, my Lord; it was given me to betray my Mistress.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Hau— Who has Plots upon her Body?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: No body; it was given me to deprive her of you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: What mean'st thou?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: To tell your Lordship that— But I am so afraid, you shoud tell agen.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I'le be secret on my Honour.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: That there is a rich Heiress not far off in love with your Lordship.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Humh— And is not this a Plot laid—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, 'tis a Plot laid.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: To betray me—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: And you'l discover it.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: To none but your Lordship: It is to betray you, but will your Lordship be sure not to speak on't agen?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I will not.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: To betray your Lordship into a Marriage with this great Fortune.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I am to tell her Name too, and how you shall come to see her, for all the Dragon her Uncle; and how you shall steal a Marriage and all.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: What say'st thou Beatrice?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Nothing but truth: Her Name is Mrs. Rich, she lives in this street, and is sick in Bed for love of you. She sent for me and gave me this Gold, with promise of much more, if I wou'd be true to her, and acquaint you with her Condition; and be instrumental in helping her to see you—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: How Beatrice; may I come to the sight of her.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: She has brib'd her Physician to joyn in the Conspiracy; he will pretend to bring an able Doctor of his Acquaintance to see her, that with him he may consult of her Disease and Cure. You are to be this Physician, and the Person in the habit of an Apothecary— which you are to provide, for we know none.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Let me alone for that!

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Then if your Lordship like her; you may there Marry her.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: A very neat Invention! Oh subtile Woman!

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: This my Lord was my Plot.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: 'Tis well laid.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: She has promis'd I shall live with her when I am Marry'd.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Thou shalt— But Beatrice, thou'lt keep thy Maiden for me, wilt thou not.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: If I find you can keep Secrets; I will trust your Lordship with any thing.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I know thou did'st love me better than thy Mistress, or her Flirking Cozen— Well, were it not for what thou hast told me, their Affronts wou'd drive me to my Country-House; where I'd live like a Hermit, and leave half the Town languishing.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: You wou'd leave my Lady a bleeding. But I hope your Lordship is better Natur'd, and more just, than to revenge the Faults of a few upon the whole Sex. I'le go put my Affairs in a posture for my getting abroad to wait on your Lordship.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: And I the mean time, will disengage my self from all concerns here, and to Iacinta's Father resign the Interest he gave me in her.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Go thy ways, Lord Credulous; how greedily he swallows the Bait with which he was caught before.
sp.l: A Fool will often run into the Snare,
But once escap'd, the Wise-man does beware.

div.head: The Fourth Act.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: COme Huswife; ask Forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I have Sir.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: But on your Knees.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Quickly down; down on your Knees, Baggage.

div.stage: Enter Hilaria with a Cain in her Hand.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Courage Cozen Iacinta, I am come to your aid: Look you Uncle, I have got as Tuff a Cain as your's.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Get you out of my Doors Huswife— So down, down on your Knees.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I do Sir—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Down, my Lord, Come you must down too.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Hold! hold! hold!

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Why Niece—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis very true Uncle, if you lay't on there, I'le lay't on here with a Vengeance: Down on your Marry-Bones—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Why look you Lady to serve you—

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Get you out of my Doors; get you out of my House.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nay Uncle, keep off, I am resolved to stand upon my Guard.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Get you gone I say, and never come near me more.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But don't you think to Domineer when I am gone, if I hear you do, I'le have about too with you Uncle, as old a Cock of the Game as you are, I'le have a Sparring Blow too with you.

div.stage: Enter Beatrice, and Toby following in a Disguise, a Suit of Four Quarters, representing the Four Parts of the World, with his Head habited like a Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Here's a Stranger enquires for you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Here's a Cavilere to Defend us; Cudgel lye thou there.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I am your Humble my Lord.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Sir, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I have had the Honour to see your Lordship in many Countries abroad, and you appear'd so pleasing to me; That returning from Travel, I could not but take England in my way— (Tho' I had formerly liv'd here six years) that I might receive the Honour of Kissing your hand; and making my self Familiar in your Lordships Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Which I covet abundantly. A Traveller cannot but be worthy my Knowledge. I venerate a Pilgrims Shooe as much as they do Saints, whose Shrines they go to visit, because it hath trod the Dust of many Countries; shall I beg Cognizance of your Name, Signior.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: My Name is Signior, Simplaio, Folio. Del no no, Wittesso At-Allo.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Bless me!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: The Counts Name is but Monosillable to this.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: This is a noble Family as I take it.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: And you are a great Fool for your pains.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: 'Tis a very Noble one in Spain. I was borne at Castile, Christen'd at Rome, Educated in Paris, return'd to Italy, left my Virginity at Venice; Sayl'd from thence to Constantinople; Travell'd to Ierusalem, and there I first Shav'd my Beard.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Uncle, he may well have a long Name, that went as far as Rome to be Christen'd.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: He appears to be a great Traveller.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: His Face shews it.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: He has indeed a right Olive-Complexion; which is a sign he has much in the Sun.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: My Lord, I hope you'l command my pardon for this Gentleman, and these Ladies, if my Respects to your Lordship makes me appear uncivil to them.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Not in the least— My Lord merits all—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: My Lord, don't you remember to have seen me in your Travels?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I begin to call you to mind, as I take it, I saw you in the Court of Spain.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Right, you did so; I was then playing a Game at Chess with the King!

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: And at Vienna, the Emperor's Court.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: The Emperor and I, the first Morning I saw you there, were at Tennis: I remember I lost a Sett for a thousand Pistols to satisfie my Curiosity of looking upon your Lordship; that was the second time I had the Honour to see you.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: This is a Great Person; behave your selves with Respect.

div.stage: A Bottle of Sack, and Glass ready for Beatrice.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: And as I take it, I saw you as I Accompany'd Cardinal Palavicina, the Popes Nephew, to the Consistory; I was at that time in his Coach.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I think you were; and I well remember, I Rid with his Holiness in His— And your Lordship gave me the Grace of a Bow, which I return'd your Lordship with so great Obeysance, that had not his Holiness caught hold on me behind; I had tumbl'd out or'e the Boot of the Coach.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: You did much Honour my Civilities.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Now we have encreas'd our Acquaintance; I'le obtrude the trouble on you, to go with me to Court some Day, and present me to the King, that I may have the Honour to kiss his Hand.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I swell with the Ambition of waiting on so Noble a Cavaliero; Now I perfectly remember you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I beg your Pardon—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Sir, pray advance, here's only a Noble stranger, one that's a great Traveller, and of my former Acquaintance: He's worth your knowledge, O Sir Cavilliero; pray receive this Gentleman into your Armes.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha! sure I know that Habit— Ha— Sirrah— You Rogue, What make you here?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Sir! Your Language is too bold.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: You take too great a Liberty to affront any Man in my House; besides, he's a Man of Quality.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'le fetch his Qualities out of him, with a Pox to him.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ah good Sir, hold Sir, or you'l make a Discovery.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ah Sir, I'le make you discover what Tricks you are playing here?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, hold—

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, hold—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ah, ah, Good Sir— Nay Sir— Good Sir— Pray good Master.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, he!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, he!

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, he!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ah Sir, I ask you Forgiveness on my Knees.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sirrah; what makes you loytering here, when I send you about Business?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ah Lord Sir, I only put on your Masquerading Suit to come to Mrs. Beatrice in, to see if she cou'd know me!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, he! Toby! Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, he! Toby! Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, he! Toby! Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I thought I should find you here; go get you home you Rogue, go.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Wou'd I was gone too.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: My Lord, won't you follow, and wait on your Cavaliero to Kiss the Kings hand; Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Your Lordship saw him in Spain, Germany and Rome; Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And bow'd to him out of the Cardinal's Coach; Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: I am amaz'd; Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What mean you, Ladies?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Ladies, Gentlemen; a good Jest— Ha, ha, ha— Laugh at it, Ha, ha— Laugh heartily, Ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: He's a witty Knave, Ha, ha, ha, my sides will burst with Laughing, Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am afraid the Rogue has play'd some Unlucky Trick—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
