sp.p: No, no— Ha, ha, ha, a Jest, a very good Jest, Ha, ha, ha; I protest my Laughing has made me Sick. I'le take my leave, Sir.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Beatrice, fetch in a Bottle of Sack. My Lord, pray drink a Glass of Sack, if you'r not Well.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: No matter.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Oh, by all means! my Lord, how came you to be so mistaken in him?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: There was a Noble Cavalier, that I often met in my Travels Sir, like this Knave, Ha, ha, ha. I protest, I thought it had been he— Well Sir, Your Man's a Witty Knave—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am glad he has made you all Merry; I was afraid he had play'd the Rogue— For which, I wou'd have so beat him— My Lord, your Servant; your Servant Sir; Ladies your Servant—

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Come Beatrice, Fill my Lord a Glass of Sack. See who Knock's at the Door, Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Here's a Woman wou'd Speak with my Lord—

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Bid Her come in.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Breedwell. Jenny, Sarah. Two Children.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Ha! Have I found you at last? Are you come again, after so many Years Absence? Cou'd you, wicked Man, think to Forsake me for ever?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: What means the Woman!

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Ah, Hard hearted Lord, You know well enough what I mean! Can you see me, and not Blush? Was it for this, that you pretended Love to me, and caus'd my Poor Parents to break off my Marriage with the Viccar's Son? And did you Marry me your self, only to leave me, and make me Wretched?

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Marry'd!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Marry'd!

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Woman! what in the Devil's name dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: I mean, your going away, and leaving of me— After you had Marry'd me: assoon as you saw me with Child, you pretended Business to London: You left me Money to keep me Six Months, but before the time expir'd, you ran beyond Sea, without letting me know whether you were gone; not sending me any thing to Maintain me in that Condition: And to encrease my Misfortunes, I had two Children at a Birth.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Does not your Lordship know me?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: An impudent Quean! I never saw her before. I know her not.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Not know your own Wife! Shameless Lord! You are a Dishonour to the Womb that bare you: Have my Cares and Miseries this Seven years so alter'd me, that you don't know me? Yes, You know me, but you won't. Ah that I had never known you, then I shou'd not have known Sorrow: You were in Hopes it would brake my Heart; but I live to plague you.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Alas poor Woman!

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Heav'n help us poor Wretches, if we must have such hard Fortune! To be forsaken by our Husbands, and left without Money in our Pocket, Cloaths to the back, and Meat or Drink for the Belly.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: The Womans Distracted; send her to Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: The Woman talks sensibly.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Ah! How dost think I have maintain'd my self, and these Two poor Children, these six Years and more: E'en with the Work of my own Hands— God help me.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Alas poor Woman!

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: It grieves me to see her Weep.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: What shou'd this mean?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It appears by the Story, that she's his Wife!

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Not my Wife, I protest.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Here's another Woman with Child enquires for my Lord.

div.stage: Enter Clappam, Tommie, a Child as out of Breath.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Let me come in— Hau, hau— I am almost dead; I am out of Breath— Oh wicked man; it is after you, that I run thus up and down, Hau, hau, hau— But now I have found you, you shall not escape me.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: What mean'st thou now?

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: I mean to cross your Marriage; you thought I was dead, or far enough from England, ne'r to trouble you more, Did you?

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: What's your Business?

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Ah that Wretch of a Husband there; that Unnatural Wretch; he Sold his own Wife, Sold his Child, Sold his own Flesh and Bloud.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: This is some Mistake.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Are you his Wife?

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Yes Madam, he Marryed me, and carried me from my Friends; he carry'd me with him beyond Sea, and when he got me there, and I began to grow Big with Child, he pretended to send me by Sea to England— To live with my Friends till he return'd— But instead of that, I was carried to Iapan; he had Sold me to the Master of the Ship, who was a Dutch-man: he Sold me, and this poor Child that was in my Belly, to Slavery and Bondage.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Which do you say is your Husband?

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: E'en this; this is he, let him deny't if he can.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: No, 'tis I am his Wife.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: You his Wife too! What, has the Wretch two Wives? That will Hang him.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Hang him; no, you'r none of his Wife.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Yes, he is my Husband.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: I say, he is my Husband, and I can prove it.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Are ye both possest? I am Husband to neither of Ye.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: We have been Marry'd this Seven Years.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: It is Six, since he Marry'd me.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Is this true, you wicked Lord?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Yes, yes, one's as true as the other.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Ah shameless Man! Dost thou confess thou hast Two Wives? Come hither little Ienny, come hither Sarah; Look you, these are the Fruits of our Marriage.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: And here's my Child too.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Look here upon these Two sweet Babies.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: And look here too: here's thy own Flesh and Bloud which thou did'st so Barberously sell.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Never were two such impudent Carrions seen.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: They are as like you, my Lord—

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Yes Lady, and so they are.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: This has the very Eyes and Mouth of him; he is so like his Lordship—

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: They are sweet Children indeed.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Ye all dream; they are neither Like me, nor Pretty, nor Nothing.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Kneel Ienny, kneel down little Sarah, and ask Father Blessing; and let's see if he can be so Unnatural to Disowne you.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: And do you kneel Tommie, ask Blessing; 'tis thy own Daddy.

sp.speaker: 3 Child.
sp.p: Father, Father, Father—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: The Devil take you for Whore's-Birds—

sp.speaker: 3 Child.
sp.p: Father, Father, Father—

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Don't you think to be gone, and Leave them; I'le follow you, and Proclaime it to all the World.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: And I'le haunt you where-e're you go; I'le be satisfi'd, if she is your Wife too: and if I find it true, I'le have Recourse to Justice; you shall be hang'd, if all the Law in England will hang you, for having Two Wives.

sp.speaker: 3 Child.
sp.p: Father, Father—

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Justice, Justice, Justice, &c.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Justice, Justice, Justice, &c.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Father, Father, Father, &c.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Now must I bestir my self.

div.stage: D. Bo. Breed. Clap. 3 Children, Beat.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: I am so amaz'd, I know not what to think of all that we have seen, and heard.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: They are both his Wives for certain.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: This wou'd have been a fine Husband for my Cozen. Now Uncle, Are you not beholden to Fortune, or your Wisdome, for her Deliverance? Cozen, let me choose a Husband for you the next time.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Iacinta, be not rul'd by her, nor hearken to her Counsel; but on all occasions, shew all ready Complyance to my Commands; for your Niece may stay in my House. I forgive you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ah Uncle, and I pardon you— Come Old-Man, Let's shake Hands; you see I am good Natur'd. So now we are all Friends.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Well, I must be gone abroad.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Fare you well, Uncle—
Now he's gone, we'l be gone too. Come Cozen, we'l spend this Afternoon in a Frolique: we'l go see a Play at the Nursery; I'le put on the Boyes Habit I made for a Masquerading Suit.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Let's go in our Scarfs, Vizards, and Masques.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You shall; but I'le have my own Humour: I'le Cock, and Strut, and so Hector the young Cits, if they come to disturb us with their Impertinences—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You come luckyly, our Plot succeeds rarely.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Have we Routed the Enemy?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Horse and Foot; he'l ne'r be able to appear in the Feild agen.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Our new Alderman Rich, and his Neice, are ready to receive e'm if he comes—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: His Wives follow'd him so close, I am afraid they have scar'd his Lordship out of Town, if not out of's Witts.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: We must find out Beatrice, and recover him; for all things are so well prepar'd—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: She's after him where er'e he is. But by what means have you compass'd the bus'ness we last spoke of?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I sent a Letter as from an unknown friend to the Alderman, to let him know there was an appointment made by his Neice, and some Gallants, to steal her away to Night; this he easily believ'd, because 'tis but what he always fears and is jealous of; he presently out of pretence to carry her abroad in's coach to take the air, has convey'd her to his Country House, which is but Eight Miles from London.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: This the Landlady told me; for she's my friend, and I have feed her, to let a Lady of my acquaintance have the command of the lodging for this night; and thither I have convey'd our counterfeit Heiresse.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And Toby is now a Grave Alderman.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I sent him one of her Uncles old suites, which I borrow'd of the Landlady.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: He's at the Tavern here waiting for orders.
Here's Beatrice now—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But where's my Lord?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: In my pursuit I saw him give his pursuers the Dodg. I gave e'm the sign to make a fault; he turn'd clear back this way, and they keep at a distance, and I am come a nearer way to meet him here.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: We are ready to receive him.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: That's well— here he comes, lets slip in there, that he may not see us together.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p:
With much a doe I have at length got clear of e'm. The
Jades, and their bawling Bastards— Father, Father, Father— I have run my self almost out of Breath.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I am glad I have found you, my Lord; I have run my self almost off my Legs to o're-take ye.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: ‛ Pox o'th Whores; my Shirt sticks to my back.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: But my Lord, are you Marry'd to any of e'm?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: O the Devil! Not I.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Nor promis'd e'm Marriage neither?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: If it should appear so hereafter, it would be an injury to the Lady; and I would not have a Hand in doing her any Wrong for the World: I Love her as my Life!

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I never saw either of e'm before. Upon my Honour, I did not.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Now I believe your Lordship; but if any thing of this this shou'd come to the Ladies Ear, it wou'd Ruine our Designe.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: But I hope she'l not hear't so soon.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: We must out-fly Report: Come, my Lord, let's instantly about it, to prevent Danger—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: But I have got no Parson yet.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: It can't be help't: I hear her Uncle will be abroad all this Afternoon, and we'l perswade her to Counterfeit a Fit of Illness; and the Doctor shall tell the Landlady, and the Servants, that she must presently take the Air, or she'l dye; that she has an Oppression of Spirit about her Heart, and that the Jogging of a Coach will relieve her; and when we get her abroad, we know what to do.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Yet I wish we had a Parson ready, for fear her Uncle shou'd be at Home, or come in by accident; then we might do't, and he in the House.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: At worst, you may contract, and break a piece of Gold betwixt you. Within, 3 Child. Father, Father, Father—

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Hark! The Beagles follow us; they have taken the Scent afresh, and come with a full Cry. Within, 3 Child, Father, Father, Father—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: The Cry comes this way— Follow me with all the hast you can, that they not come within view of us.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: So, now the Children are sent home, let's to the place of Rendezvous.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Here's the Tavern; Enter—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Come Lovel, they are gone to the Tavern to look for us.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am the worst man i'th world, to Converse with this sort of Cattle.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Thou ought'st to be civil to e'm upon Account of the Kindness they have done for thee at my Request.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Will not my Money excuse my Company.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Did not I condescend to visit a Pair of Honest women at your request? Aye, and visit them a second time; and can you in Conscience refuse to Accompany me now—?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Your first Visit was made by my perswasions; but the second, was the Effect of your own Inclinations.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Well; but come along, if you like not your Company, be gone assoon as you will.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: 'Tis e'en so; your Lover and my Gallant are gone in after e'm: We'l put off our Frollique of going to the Nursery, and I'le adventure into the Tavern; to see after what manner they Treat e'm.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: But shou'd they know you—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: They know you: they can't in this Disguise; but if they do, 'twill pass for a Frolique—

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Breeder, Clappam, Drawer in Tavern.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: What Wine do you please to drink, Ladies?

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Sack and Claret; Is it good?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: We have as good as any is in England.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: But you Son of a Whore, shall we have any of it?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I'le bring you that shall please you—

div.stage: Breedwell and Clappam, both Sing and Dance about.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: I found a Thief a Managing
My Natural on a Chair,
I pull'd out Focus speedily—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Ha: Merry Lasses!

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: As Merry as Birds in a fair Morning.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Or Crickets in a warm Chimney.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Fill some Wine Boy— This will encrease your Mirth—

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Here Careless, you Son of a Whore, here's to you.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I thank you Mrs. Breedwell.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Lady, my Service to you—

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Damn your Complement. My Service to you— You'd have said as much as that to an Honest Woman—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ladies, I can't talk at your rate; but if you are for down-right Drinking— have at you.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Here Careless, you Damn'd Confounded Dog, give me your Hand.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Pray mind your own Intrigue; we are agreed.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Mrs. Breedwell— What right have you to choose your Man before me?

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: I have been acquainted with him longer than you—

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Mr. Careless, do you like a Woman e're the better for being an Old Acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: He chose me, and that's a signe he likes me better than you—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I took the first that came to my hand.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Yes, she's so forward.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am then shut out for a wrangler.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Rot your humour! that you'l be so disobliging to any Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: He's as Dull as an Alderman.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Madam! there's a young Gentleman at the dore desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Come Lovel, here's both their Healths to you.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Madam, I had a sight of you as you came up staires, and was extreamly taken with you: pray oblige me so far as to own me for your acquaintance, and introduce me into the Company, which I much desire, for your sake.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Sir, you may Command me. Lord 'tis the prettyest man— Nay Sir, you shall come in— here are none but friends.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir, you must not refuse a Ladies Invitation.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: I fear I shall be uncivil.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That you can hardly be in our Company.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir, these Ladies Healths to you—

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Come on Sir, Ladies, To your good Healths.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: And here's Mr. Lovels Health.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: I am ready to pledge it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And to make it go down the pleasanter, there's That to sweeten your Wine and yours.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Were we but sure such sand lay at the Bottom of the Sea, wee'd drink the Ocean off.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Look you Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And now Ladies, I thank you for the good service you have done for me.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Will you leave us then?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: My absence is no Injury, now you have got another Man—

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: But Sir.—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And I have a little Bus'ness.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Damn Business; when Wine and Women are in the case▪

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: It is of great Concern—

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Sir, can there be affaires of greater Importance than Drinking and Wenching?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: To tell you true Sir, he's going to see a Lady that he's in Love with.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: What sots Love makes of men.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Your servant Gallants—

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Your servant.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Your servant.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: I hope he'l find Compunction of heart e're he gets there, repent of's sin, and so come back agen.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: As I live, this is the prettiest youth— Come let's be freely merry—

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: I love freedom in my Mirth; Come Sir, will you pledg me on that Ladies Lipps? Ten go downs upon Reputation.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Sir! Ile pledge you here, and there, and every where.

div.stage: Kisse each other woman, and then change and kisse their own.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: I here Musick.
Come in you sons of Melody.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Come my little Squire of the Body, You and I will have a Dance together.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Nay, keep to your own man.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: I have as much reason to Dance with him as you—

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: You Lye— and you take Tobacco, and I am satisfi'd.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: What Interest have you in him, I wonder?

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: To beat you with your own Cudgel: know that I am his old acquaintance, and he chose me.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: That was because he thought I had been engag'd elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: So, now they Quarrel for him. And I am in the Condition my friend was just now.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Ladies, I am ready to serve you in any kind, but then you must take me by turnes.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I'le ease you of half your Burden; Mrs. Breedwell, you and I won't part so.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Strike up you Rogues.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Now Sir, let me oblige you to Dance a Jigg.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Lord, Mrs. Breedwell, you are so forward— I can oblige him to't as well as you.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: They are at it agen. A pox of this smock-fac'd Rogue. I must be forc't to kick this fellow out of Company. Some Wine Boy. Mrs. Clappam, you are not so obliging to day as you us'd to be.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Not I Sir, I Swear, I begg your pardon: I'le pledge you Sir.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: How your Dancing has made you sweat: Let we wipe your face. How long Sir have you known that Lady?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Some few days.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Have you ever bin concern'd with her?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: No, but 'tis my present business.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Have a Care how you venture: I wou'd not say so much but that I have a kindness for you.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Is she not well?

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Pretty well agen now: but she's not quite out of the Surgeons hands yet.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: I am just now in the humour, but I had rather have your Company.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Take your leave, and I'le follow you to the next Tavern—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You must pledg me now—

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: That they may not suspect, go you first—

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: That's not fair play Mris. Breedwel.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: If you are Jealous, wipe his face your self Some. Some Wine Boy. To your good Thoughts.—

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: How do you like Mrs. Breedwell?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Well enough.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: On my word you'l not find a finer Woman in Town of her age: How old do you think she is?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Eighteen.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Gemine! I am as much.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: I may be mistaken.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Why she lay In a year a goe of her fifth Child, and were't not for some defect in her Teeth which taints her Breath a little, she's not to be dislik'd.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: How malicious are Women against one another! Let us alone to discover each others faults.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Has she not acquainted you with her Lodging?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: You need not be Jealous, let me but know where yours is.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Hark you Sir.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I must be forc't to kick these two out of the Room; I hate whispering, it spoiles good company.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Enough— we have done Sir— slip from the Company and go home. I'le come to you.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Agen.—

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: What are you for?

sp.speaker: 2. Draw
sp.p: There are a Couple of Seamen in the next Room desires to Entertain you with a Dance.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Bid'em come in— Play away, Give e'm what Wine they'l drink, and clap't to our reckoning.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Bid'em come in— Play away, Give e'm what Wine they'l drink, and clap't to our reckoning.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: One of you Two Ladies I hope will entertayn us with a Song.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Mrs. Clappam, you have a good Voice.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Before you hear't I'le lay a Wager 'tis either a Drinking, or a Bawdy Song.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Is there not Phillis in't?

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Then it may not be Bawdy. Come, let's hear your Old out-of-Fashion Song.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: 'Tis Call'd the Agreement.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Now I'le steal away.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.l: Come peevish Lovers, hear and see
How my Love and I Agree:
We are in sweet embraces twin'd;
I am Constant, and she is Kind.

div.stage: Enter second Drawer with a Letter, and gives it Careless.

sp.speaker: 2. Draw.
sp.p: Sir, a Porter has brought this Letter for you, and stayes for an Answer.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: I'le take this occasion to slip away.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: I'le o're take you—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Gallant, I know not what's the Cause, but I am very Mellancholly: pray come and spend the rest of this afternoon with me; for I find an Inclination to your company, perhaps the sight of you may cure me:

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: This 'tis to have the acquaintance of honest Women, they presently grow troublesome.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Why Sir?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p:
Why, if they be of the dull sober sort, a man can hardly get acquainted with them, but they fall flat in Love with him: if
they be of a sprightly gay humour; they presently grow impertinent, they will ever be sending such Notes as these to a man, or running after him.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: But is she handsome that sends you this Invitation?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yes: hang her, she's well enough.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Then you shou'd tak't for a kindness—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yes: just as a Husband does when his Wife jogg'd me by the Elbow, and askes him the Question. I wonder Women han't Wit enough to know when a Man cares for their Love, or their Company: to be sure, when he has a mind to either, he'l be coming or sending to them.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: But won't you go?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Dost think I'le leave good sociable Company to go to a dull honest Wench?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: She'l take it ill.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I have a better opinion of her Wit, than to think she'd desire me if she knew how the case stands. It wou'd be as unreasonable in her, as to invite a hungry Man from a well-furnish'd Table, to go & look upon the Picture of a Banquet, where he can only feast his eye, but never allay his appetite. Boy, bid the Porter tell her he can't find me— I'le make such Visits when I can have no better Company.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: But where are our Women?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: One of e'm went out just before the Song, and bid me tell you—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Speak out you Rogue—

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: That she was gone to th' place appointed.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Young Squire, you don't play me square play. You ought not to take up another mans Dice—
And where's she that sung?—
Do you know where the Lady is that was here but e'en now?

sp.speaker: 2. Draw.
sp.p: She's gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Whither? Are you going to whisper too? speak out—

sp.speaker: 2. Draw.
sp.p: I suppose that Gentleman knows. She sent to desire him to make haste?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p:
Get you both down; We'l pay at the Bar— [Ex. Drawers Sir, you make too bold with me; to take one Mrs. from me,
was Ill-manners; to Rob me of both, Malice and Ill-Nature—!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I do't by way of Reprizal; you have took one from me, and I have got two from you.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I take one from you—!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yes; I have had a long Intrigue with the Lady nam'd Hilaria: And I hear you are become her Servant—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Hilaria!

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I was ignorant of any such pretensions.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: I shall spoile your Markets there too: I shall tell her, that she's Impertinent to send after you, and all that— and when you can find no better Company, you'l come to her, and all that—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Nay then; I'le take another course with you. Come Sir.—

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Surely, you'l not be so mad to fight for one you don't love?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Look you Sir, tho' I scorn to tell her so, or any of her Sex: yet I do love her, will love her, and must love her: and no Body else shall love her—

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: But I do— shall, and will love her— better then you—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Come: give me a proof on't then—

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I will give you a proof of 't— ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Hilaria!

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Alas poor Gallant— ha ha ha— observe, now you are Cheated of three Mrs's. ha ha ha— fare you well— Gallant.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Hark you, stay—

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: No; Women are so impertinent— Men will come after them, when they love them— adieu—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Gad— she's too unconscionable, to deprive me of two Mrs's. and then to run away her self— and now she knows I love her, she'l insult o're me— and those Damn'd Whores to serve me such a Dog trick— I thought they had some honour in them; But I find that Women are by Nature guilty; For be they Whores, or no Whores, they will jilt ye—

div.head: The Fifth Act.
div.stage: Enter Deboastado in the Habit of a Physician, Toby like an Old Rich Alderman.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: MR. Doctor, I desire no more of your Consultations with my Neice; I say no more, but I smell a Fox.

sp.speaker: D. B.
sp.p: What do you mean Sir?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I say no more: but some Wiser than some.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: That Sir, was the very reason, why the Doctor brought me with him, thinking I might observe some Circumstances which might discover the Nature of your Neices Disease, of which he yet remains doubtful.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: And you discover'd, that it was good for her to go Abroad in a Coach, to take the Air.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and I'le give you a Reason for't; for want of Exercise the Bloud grows thick, and corrupts in the Veins, which are the Channels Nature has design'd for: Sir, does it not stand to reason, that Motion and Exercise which opens the Veins, rarifies the Bloud, and gives it a free Passage; should it not in some measure work it's Effects on your Neice.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I say no more, but that some are Fools, and some are Physicians.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I will maintain it against the Learned'st Professors in Town, that it will do your Neice more good to Joult about one Hour in a Coach every Morning and Evening for a Month, than to take Ten Purges a day.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I am much of your mind, Mr. Doctor; and I say no more, but that it is not good for Sick Folks to go abroad in the Air.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Her Sickness is for want of Air.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: And I say no more, but that some peoples reasons for her going Abroad, is, that she's an Heiress.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I hope you don't think that I am an Instrument in any Designe.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I say no more, but that there are Blades upon the Randan, that would Feel her Pulse, and stir her Bloud to some purpose; and that's one reason why 'tis not good for her to go Abroad.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I beg your Pardon, Sir, I spoke as a Physician in Consideration of her Health, and Mr. Doctor within was partly of my mind.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: He was of the mind too, that my Cook-maid wou'd not dye yesterday: and I say no more, but that she dyed within two hours after.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Physicians sometimes say what they think will best please their Patients.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: And you thought 'twould please her best to be Gadding abroad; I say no more, but that if her Bloud want stirring, I'le get her a Husband.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Yes Sir, that will do best of all.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Sir, Then we agree at last: and I say no more, but that his Lordship shall go without her.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: What Lord, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: A Friend, a Neighbour of mine sends me word, that she's in Love with a Foolish Fantastick Lord.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: What is this Lord?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I say no more, but that he has been a Traveller, is very conceited, and very ridiculous.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: What is his Name?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: You may as soon call o're a Troop of Horse as Name him; I know no more, but that he has two Wives already, that he is a very great Fool; and I say no more, but that I'le have my Neice into the Country to Morrow.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p:
Let me tell you Beatrice, this Alderman is an old
Rooke, he smells Powder a great way off.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Does he suspect you?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: He suspects every body: he has heard the whole Story of her being in Love with me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: It comes from our House, I warrant you▪ but was it not very Unfortunate for us, that he should come Home just as we had convinc'd the Landlady and Servants, that it was necessary for the Lady to go abroad?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: The Coach sent for, and all.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: And when he came, he was so earnest for you to be gone, being a Stranger, and kept such a fidling about his Niece, that you could not break a Piece of Gold as we design'd, and make a Contract.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Fate was indeed very malicious.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: But how does your Lordship like her?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: She's a Miracle! I protest I saw not so great a Rariety in all my Travels.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What a pretty Mouth she has, so Little; and her Neither-Lip so Cherry-like; and then she's such a Pattern of Modesty and Innocence, one wou'd wonder how she got the Confidence to be in Love.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: She's a rare Creature!

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: She loves the very ground you go on.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: O Beatrice, if I had her—

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: She's resolv'd by some Stratagem or another, to get to you to Night; therefore be sure you be not out of the way.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I'le go directly to my Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Be careful you are not seen i'th Streets; for if those two Women once get sight of you, their Tongues will blow up your Credit.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I'le be gone, lest they shou'd come and find me here.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: You may venture forth, he's gone.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: 'Twas damn'd ill Luck, that we had ne're a Parson here; The Business had been done.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: He fail'd of bringing one with him; and if we had provided a Parson, our Forwardness might have given him Cause of Suspition; but Disappointment does make Men more Eager.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: So much for that now, Beatrice; being at Leasure, let us examine how Matters stand 'twixt you and me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Just as they did, on my part.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: But methinks now you have seen how well ● Acted the Gentleman, Traveller, and the old Alderman, you should love me much better for my Ingenuity.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: In the first Shape, you appear'd so much like a Gentleman; and in this, so like an old Rich Alderman, that I shall never endure to see you your own Man agen.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: When I am neither Gentleman, nor Alderman, I shall be Toby still; and I am no more now.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: But if we Two shou'd Marry, how shou'd we do to Live?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Live, well enough; we'l live by our Wits.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Then I must maintain you and my self too.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why Beatrice? do'st think I have not as much Wit as Thee?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: No marry han't you.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: This day I have given the World sufficient Proofs of my Wit..

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I doubt not but e're Night, to give you a better Proof of mine, than any you have, or can give of yours.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: P'shaw, p'shaw— Yonder's my Master, go and acquaint him how Matters succeed.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The truth is, she plaid the Tyrant with thee; but you deserv'd that, and more.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Well, were not the Use and Conversation of Women absolute necessary for Man, I wou'd forswear the whole Sex.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
I know by the Constitution of your Body, that you'd not
be able to keep that Oath: but, I advise you to Forswear all but one.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: That is; you'd have me Marry.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes; you'l find more Comfort in a Wife, than in Ten Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: If what you say, be true, Why do most Husbands in this Age, (which I take to be wiser than any that's past) Turn away their Wives, and keep Wenches? at least, those that are so Civil to keep a Wife, they keep a Mistress besides?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And if it be not true, Why do the great Wenchers at last forsake all their Mistresses for a Wife? for, we find most of them Marry at the Long-run; Nay, generally they prove the best Husbands: And the reason is, they have experimented the Folly of that Lewd Course of Life.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I had never so good an Opinion of Marriage as now; for, this Dog-trick that these two Gilting Jades shew'd me in Leaving me so in the Lurch, has lessen'd e'm in my Esteem, to the degree of Honest Women; and now the Scales are equal, the first of either Party that oblidges me, draws it down on that side.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Then I hope Hilaria will turn the Ballance.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: If the Devil is minded to lose a Gamester, let him venture to make her and me Friends.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Sir, We are still Successful in our Designs; it is drawing to a Conclusion, therefore be in a Posture to receive us.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'le give u'm Notice within: you'l take Care of the rest.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: The Parson and the Fidlers, I believe, are Drunk together, and falne asleep in the Tavern; but I'le Marshal e'm presently.

sp.speaker: Bear.
sp.p: And I'le back to my Imployment.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: How now Gallant.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: O Madam.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You are very merry Gallant.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I have no reason to be otherwise. Why do you Josle me?

div.stage: Sings, and walks about two or three times, and Iosle one another.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And why do you Josle me?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You walk in my way.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: 'Tis you walk in my way.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Get farther off.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Go you farther off.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I was here first.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Then you may be gone first.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I have Business here.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What, to see me?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: No—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yes, in my Conscience, you was coming to see me.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Now I think on't, so I was, on purpose to let you see that I am alive; for I believe you thought I had either hang'd my self (for the Trick you put on me to day) or had broke my Heart with Sighing for your Absence, with whom I am too desperately in Love; but believe me, I have not yet broke so much as a Butten, and may I brake my Neck, when I do, either for Love of you, or any Woman alive.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yet you love me.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I love you well enough, because you are Unlucky; and was not Honesty in the case, I should love you better; but as it is, your are in a desperate Condition.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Must I then despair?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You are for Matrimony, and that I hate; I can no more endure a Wife, than a standing Dish of Meat.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You think then I am in Love with you.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p:
Think it, Ha, ha, ha— As though I did not know That by your following me up and down; what came you to the Taverne for after me? And for what came you hither now, if you an't in Love with me? And what made you seduce the Ladies
from me, but that you had a mind to have me all your self?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I vow, now you put me in mind on't, I may be in Love with you: but you say my Case is desperate; then desperate must be the Cure, and I must e'ne resolve to be your Mistress or Wench; or what you will.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: That's your only Remedy. I am a Bird of prey, and flie at all.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Nay, then I'm a dead Woman still; for, you'l soon take a Flight from me, to another.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But when I have catch'd my Prey, I take my Belly full of it; I never leave it till I am Gorg'd.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And will your Stomack come to you agen?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yes sometimes, but Generally some Ravenous Fowl or another picks up my Leavings, and flies away with't.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But wou'd you have no more care of me?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: My Care wou'd signifie but little; for, a man seldom finds either▪ Money or a Woman in the same place he left e'm.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But they say 'tis a Rule amongst you Men, not to leave the Women you Debauch; but if they prove Constant, to provide for e'm.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Provide for u'm! Is it not enough we Teach e'm a Trade, by which they may get their Livings? but you will not want providing for, you have a good Portion: but if I wou'd, you your self, in a short time, would be for Change.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well Careless, we'l do nothing rashly; I'le in, and consider on't; and some other time I'le tell you more of my mind.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But let me give you this Caution; be not deceived with the vain Considerations of Virtue, Modesty, Honour, Chastity, Reputation, and the like; these are Bugg-Words that aw'd the Women in former Ages, and still fool a great many in this; and if once these idle Notions get into your Thoughts, I shall give you over for a lost Woman.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: The common Practice of my Sex may prevail much evil Example makes twenty Sinners to the Devil's one— Adieu.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Adieu.

div.stage: Enter D. Boastado in Masquerade, Reading a Letter.

body.p: This Night is to be the Burial of one of my Uncles Maids, who dyed Yesterday Morning; put your self in Masquerade, and stand over-against Mr. Muckworth's House, for near to that is the Church-Yard; when you see the Corps pass that way, Sing these Words— (Hums to himself) then whatsoever you see, be not startled; for, it is all but Designe to affright the People, and make e'm Run away; come you to the Coffin, and instead of a Corps; you shall find Her, that for Love of you, Attempts thus to make an Escape.
This is notably contriv'd; what a Witty Wife shall I have?

I am inform'd by Beatrice, that there will be Dancing at Mr. Muchworths; we will venture in amongst them as Masqueradors, and she has promis'd there shall be a Parson ready to Marry us, and then in spite of my Uncle, I shall for ever be

sp.p: Here comes Company; I will Retire till they are gone past.

div.stage: Enter Careless, Leading in Mrs. Breedwel and Clappam, Musicions playing before them.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Now Ladies, you may pull off your Masques; you'r no strangers to one another.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Mrs. Clappam.

div.stage: Clap. Breed. pull off their Masques.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Mrs. Breedwel.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I know you wonder to see one another here, but both of you came to'th Tavern on the same account.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: On what account.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: To see what was become of the young Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: I love you for that—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Nay, Mrs. Breedwel, I was behind you when you ask'd the Drawer what was become of him; it seems he fail'd you both, of your Assignation.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: S'life! did she dare to have an Intrigue with my Man?

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Your Man!

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Yes, my Man, you impudent Hussy; I'le scratch your Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Touch me if you dare.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: If I dare?

div.stage: Breed. Clap. Fights, and tare one another about.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: So, so; enough, enough; Brave Girles both—

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Dare me!

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: You, what are you?

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: A Degree above you, I think.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Yes, to you are; for I am not Whore and Bawd too, as you are.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: You han't Wit enough to be a ●●wd; and scarce Beauty enough, to Drive on the Vocation of Whoring: And let me advise you to make much of those Cloaths you have on, for that Face will not be able to bring you a New Gowne agen.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: And do you make much of the Embroyder'd Bodyes you use to run to Playes in the last Summer; neither your Beauty nor your Wit will ever bring you such an other Pair: You may speak French long enough, before you get such agen.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: My Back is not my Wardrobe, as your's is; I had a New Gown but a Month agoe.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: What, the Mourning-Gown you bought at Second Hand. A Woman of the Town needs no Curses, when she once comes to a Black-Cloath-Gown, and Plain Linnen; that is their Last Refuge in point of Cloaths; and when that's worn out, she must on with the Strip't Semar, and turn Bulker: at which Trade I hope to see you suddenly.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p:
And I as suddenly expect to see you so Miserable, as to
abuse Charity, to relieve your own necessities, and go up and go up and down with a purse to all your Acquaintance, to gather relief for some pretended poor Woman that is sick, or in Prison.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Enough, enough; bravely perform'd on both sides, you faught well▪ and you scold well.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: If you had been here, I would have so tew'd that spawn of a Sempstress—

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: And I would so have claw'd off that Shooemakers Daughter, that she should have thought it worse than her last Child, or her last Clap, or the scuffle she had with the Sedan-men, when they tore the Cloaths off her back for 4 s. which she ow'd 'em at least half a year.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: And you should have scap'd no better than you did when the Coach-man met you at the New Exchange, that you bilk'd off his Faire after five hours Ramble.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: No more, come a Truce, a Truce; you serv'd one another no more than you both serv'd me, I have reason to be angry with you on account of your leaving my Company for that fair, smooth, Chitty-fac'd Stranger, that neither of you ever saw before.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Ah, he was such a pretty Gentleman, and had such a boon Meen—

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: But the Devil a penny of money in his Pocket: I paid the whole reckoning; I had a good mind to have sent him to you in revenge, that he might have bilked you both, for his jilting me.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: And Bilking is so us'd now a days, that 'tis not more hard for a man to find a woman with whom he may safely venture, than 'tis for a woman to meet with a man, who the next morning, or as soon as she has been kind to him, will not say, Y'gad Madam I have got no money about me, I had damn'd ill luck at play, but I am going to receive some this Afternoon, and if you'l let me know where I shall be so happy as to meet you anon in the Evening, you shall find none more a Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: And if you make an appointment, he meets you no more; then he goes to pay off his Taylors Bill at the day promis'd: hang me if I was not serv'd so three times the last week.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p:
Men are grown so base, that 'tis enough to make any woman
for swear keeping Company,— but if that young Gentleman had serv'd me so, I Vow, I should not have been vex'd.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: And I had rather he should have serv'd me so, than failed of coming, as he promis'd.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I find both of you have a kindness for him; 〈◊〉 am perswaded, when you see him agen, that you will not be so fond of him. Come shake hands and be Friends, and I will carry you to him; he shall have his choyce, and I'le be content with the other.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Mrs. Breeder, come Kiss and be Friends.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Now put on your Masques, and in here with me.

sp.speaker: D. B.
sp.p: So, they are gone, and in good time: Here comes the Burial, I'le stand close.

div.stage: Toby in the habit of a Bearer, 4 Bearers with a Coffin on a Beare; 4 Maids in white, bearing up the 4 corners of the Sheet; they walk round the Stage, set down the Corps as to rest themselves; attended with some few followers.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Come let's rest a little.

sp.speaker: 3. Bearer,
sp.p: Ay, set down, set down.

sp.speaker: 1. Maid:
sp.p: Ah poor Betty.

sp.speaker: 2. Maid:
sp.p: Ay, she was as good a natur'd Maid—

sp.speaker: 3. Maid:
sp.p: And as pretty a Servant as ever liv'd in the Parish.

sp.speaker: 4. Maid:
sp.p: She's in Heaven, I hope, poor Wench.

sp.speaker: Deb.
sp.p: Wake all the Dead, what ho, what ho—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: and all the Bear. Hark—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Who's there?

div.stage: Beatrice in the Coffin speaks with a mournful voyce.

sp.speaker: 4. Maids.
sp.p: Hark, Hark.

sp.speaker: Deb.
sp.p: The Windows are op't, the doors unbar'd, come from the Church, and the Church-yard.

sp.speaker: d. Bearer:
sp.p: The Voyce is this way.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Ist Bearer:
sp.p: No, 'tis in the Coffin, in the Coffin Neighbour.

div.stage: Enter 4 Ghosts, a Men, and 2 Women.

sp.speaker: 4 Ghosts:
sp.p: Make roome, make roome.

sp.speaker: Deb.
sp.p: The World's at an end—

sp.speaker: 4 Ghosts, Beat.
sp.p: And we come, we come.

div.stage: The Women in long winding Sheets, the Men with Mufflers, Caps, white Cloaths, Wastcoats, Drawers, Breeches, Stockings & Pumps.

sp.speaker: Tob. and all the Bearers.
sp.p: Look, look, look.

div.stage: Beatrice rises upright in the Coffin, in a Winding-Sheet.

sp.speaker: All 4 Maids:
sp.p: Ah, ah, ah, ah, ah, ah,

div.stage: Bearers, Maids, and Followers, all run out speaking.

sp.speaker: 4 Ghosts:
sp.p: Away, away, Lovers away.

div.stage: Deb. helps Beatrice down, and carries her into Muchworth's house. Deb. Beat. Ex.
Enter Lovel, Jacinta, the Scene changes, and a Room in Muchworth's House.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why Iacinta, do you fear your love will wrong your duty.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: You know my Fathers command; if I marry you, I disobey him.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And if you do not, you'r unjust to Love:

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I will still be true to Love: I will never Marry any other man for your sake.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But if your Father Command, will you not obey?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Never—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Not to obey his Commands in Marrying, will have the same event, as to disobey him now in Marrying me.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: 'Twill not then be disobedience, though Parents have power to command us not to Marry.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ah Iacinta, was your Love like mine, you would not stand upon such nicities; a perfect Love inspires those minds with courage, where it inhabits.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I love you so well, I will not make you unhappy: Till I can bring a Portion with me, I will not be your Wife.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I was discarded to make room for that Pretender, whom we have now defeated; he being removed, your Father will soon be reconciled.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Endeavour then to get his consent.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Twill be a greater expence of time and labour to get his consent before Marriage, than to reconcile him after: when all things are once done, and not to be recall'd, Men are soon pacifi'd.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: It may be more easie, but not so secure; Old Age is very exceptions, wherefore excuse me if I dare not venture to disoblige a Father, whose Love may be considerable, and an Advantage to me.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Come leave off your Sneaking pittiful Love; my Gallant has brought some Company, Let's Dance, and be Merry; here mey come, strike up Musick.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But we want Men—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You'l have more Company presently; the Parson is doing Execution in the next Room.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Here's my Uncle; we'l have him in. Come Uncle, will you make One in a Country-Dance?

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: What's the matter here? What are you doing here? What, are Candles Lighted in every Room? And what does Musick here?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I believe you are Fudled, Uncle, you are so full of Questions.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: I say, What is all this for?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Give me leave, Iacinta, to pretend this our Wedding-Night; and that all this is on that Account.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: If he resents it ill, I shall soon undeceive him.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: What, will no body speak? Daughter, what's the Occasion of all this?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The Occasion, Sir, is such, that she is afraid to tell you; and I should be loath to let you know it, but that we hope your Pardon; without which we cannot be truly Merry.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: What's the Matter, Mr. Lovel?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: From this Posture you may guess.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: What mean you by it?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: To beg at once, your Pardon and your Blessing.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Ha▪ Is it so—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It will be otherwise with u'm anon, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: You are Marryed then?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: It was their Fate, Sir; the business is done.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Now do I hope my Uncle will take pett at the Marriage, and give Me all his Estate when he dyes, to vex his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Rather than you shall see a Groat on't, I would give it to Hospitals, which is the worst use a man can put his money to; because the Poor are always Cheated on't,— Mr. Lovel, rise. If you do well, and prove a good Husband, I have all I can desire; which is, to see my Daughter well dispos'd of; and I shall do well by you: If you prove an ill Husband, she may thank her self, and her Disobedience will be punish'd in the event.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Lord, Uncle, that you should do this on purpose to spight me.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: I believe, you was an Instrument in the design.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nay, Uncle, I must confess you have over-reach'd me clearly.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But, Sir, my being here, is on another account. I come to desire you, to use your Authority with your Niece, and keep her at home; for I can be no where, either about business, or taking my Recreation, but she presently comes and disturbs me; insomuch, that if you don't take some speedy order with her, I must be forced to leave the Town to avoyd her company.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Pray take her along with you, and you'l free me of a greater trouble, for she's my Vexation all the day long.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
'Tis true, Uncle, that Gentleman and I have been a little troublesome to one another; for you know, he came to sollicite me in the way of Matrimony, which I don't much approve of; for it makes Folks fall out: The first day of Marriage, is the last day of Love. I lik'd him well enough for a Gallant, and if he would accept
of me for a Mistriss or so? but he had a foolish scruple of Conscience, nothing would serve him but Marriage, and so away came I▪ this is all, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: If you will have my Opinion in the case, you were cut out one for the other, and 'tis pitty two houses should part you; therefore, if she'l agree to your desires, or you conform to hers, 'tis all one to me, you have my consent to either; all that I desire, is, that you'l make an end quickly, that I may be clear of her company.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Then Sir, you may either go into the Country, or stay in Town, if you please, with danger of being troubled with me; for, I absolutely declare against Marriage, and if nothing else will serve your turn, you may go where you will, and do what you please, I'le have nothing to do with such an unreasonable man as you are.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: To Convince you, Mr. Muchworth, that what she says is not true, but what, on the contrary, I am for having Her for a Mistress, and She is for being my Wife; here are a couple of Ladies, to whom, on or off, I have been Gallant this 7 or 8 years, and they can witness, I have coutinually rail'd against Marrying Mrs. Clapham, Mr. Breeder, what say you?

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Yes; Sir.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Now Lady, if you are not for what I propos'd, you may e'n keep your Maiden-head till it stinks, and is not fit for man to meddle with.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I except against your Witnesses, they are brib'd, and rather than such a Lying man as you shall have it, i'le keep it still.

div.stage: Enter De Boastado, Beatrice like a Ghost.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: What new Masque is this?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Some Masquers, hearing the Musick as they were passing by, are come in to Dance with us.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Do you know me?

div.stage: To Jacinta in a squeeking voyce.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Not I Sir.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Do you know me?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You should be a Catt, by your little squeeking voyce.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Iacinta, let us take this occasion to slip into the next Room to the Parson; now with security we may perfect our desires.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Do you know me?

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: When I see your face, i'le tell you.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Look you Sir.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Is't your Lordship?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: My Lord:

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Has your Lordship (out of a Frollick) rob'd the Church-yard for a Companion? If so, you have but a cold Bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: No, feel here, she's warm flesh and blood.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Marry Sir, she rellishes well in the hand.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, who is she?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: She is my Wife, Lady, my Wife; I have Married a Lady, a Lady, that has some forty or fifty thousand pounds to her Portion; I took her by way of Cordial, to revive my Spirits, much weaken'd by the grief I had for loosing your Daughter.

div.stage: Enter Toby, Alderman-like, three Bearers, one having Toby's habit in his hand.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Neighbours, here, here she is; Aye, here she is.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Who are these?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You'l see anon.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Keep off the Ministers of Death, this is a living body.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: She is my Maid, i'le have her agen, she shall serve her year out.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Good Mr. Alderman, you are deceived, this is your Niece.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: My Niece is at home in Chamber.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: No, Sir; but your Maid is at home, and as dead as a Herring; it was not a Corps, but a Quick Body, that came out of your house in the Coffin: it was not your Maid you suppose, but your Niece: and now, I think, my Wit hath bin too quick for you all.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Niece, come away from him.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: You cannot have Her, she is my Wife.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Are you married then already?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: For certain?

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: The Parson is still in the House.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Then, Sir, see your Alderman, your Fellow-Traveller and Toby, all in one.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Toby!

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Toby!

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: This's some new Trick.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: And now, I think our Wits have been too quick for your Lordship. Who have I married here? I would fain see, but I dare not.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I will inform your Lordship who your Wife is, as yet I know her better than your Lordship. I had here in Town three Mistresses, of which, one of 'em was very young and very pretty, and but newly debauch'd: I thought it great pity, she should drive that Trade: and therefore advis'd her, to get her a Husband before she had quite ruin'd her Credit: to advance her Design, she took the Name of Alderman Rich's Niece, and this morning took the same Lodging too; and, by the Story, I guess, this must be She you have married.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: The Alderman and his Niece went this morning out of Town.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: O! I am undone—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— if your Lordship has any Grief at your Heart, go to bed, and take a Sup of your Cordial, ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Since your Lordship has bin so kind, to take one of my Mistresses of off my Hand, I'le make you some requital in releasing you of your Wives. See, My Lord, these are my other two; they shall never trouble your Lordship more, upon the the account of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: All the right of a Husband, that I have in You, I resign to that Lady.

sp.speaker: Clap.
sp.p: I do the same.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, you have got one Wife, and lost two.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Now Marriage has made us one, our Wishes are compleat.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: My Lord, now you have drawn your Lot, see whether Fortune has sent you a Blank or a Prize.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ay, ay, come, Mrs. Grace, you may e'en shew your Face.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: Married to a Wench— I am abus'd, cheated—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, and so they are all— Beatrice discovers herself Omnes Beatrice!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: How, Mrs. Beatrice!

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Beatrice I am, but not your Beatrice now.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Are thou married then?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Yes, to a Lord. Who has most Wit now, Toby?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Am I then forsaken? Oh! that the Fates would be so kind, to lend a Dagger, or a Knife, to an incensed Lover.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What wou'd you do?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I would kill my self, to be reveng'd on thee.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: There are Knives enough for that Execution in the Table-basket that stands i'th' Hall.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Are there?—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But how came you to surprise us with this new Turn?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Out of pure Kindness to his Lordship; rather than he should marry a Wench, I cast my self away upon him.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: My Lord, comfort your self with the old Rule, Since 'tis no better, it's well it is no worse.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Take her to you, My Lord, had She not bin your Friend, you had bin in a much worse condition.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Though my Daughters Servant, she is a good Gentlewoman born, and near related to us.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: 'Tis well your Lordship has light of an honest Woman.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: One proof of my Honesty is, I promis'd your Lordship my Maiden-head, and now 'tis at your Service.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Look, look here, ungrateful Beatrice, look how on my Breast thy Perfidiousness revenge.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Ay, I see.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Then, Toby, die, die the Death of a faithful Lover.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ay.

div.stage: Toby strikes himself on the Breast, and falls down.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Ay, Toby, what hast thou done?— Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha—

div.stage: Beat. looks on his Breast, & takes up a great Candle.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What dost laugh at?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Look here, he has mistaken a great Candle for a Case-Knife.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: He scar'd me: it gave way, and, I thought verily, I had seen it run into his Body.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Rise, Toby, you have only greased your Doublet.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I durst have sworn, I had left a Knife in my Heart.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: If you go to the Basket agen, be sure you bring a Knife with you.

sp.speaker: Tob,
sp.p: No; me thought, Self-Murder was a great Sin; and now I have consider'd on't a little, I'm glad to see my self alive agen: and now, rather than kill my self for You, or any Woman breathing, I would first see the Souls of a hundred thousand of 'em ramm'd into a Morter-piece, and shot into a Duth Fire-ship, and so I leave you to his Lordship; and to let you see, I am my own man again; I and my Friends will dance at your Wedding▪ Come, give me my habit.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: My Lord, you see I did not any thing for want of an Husband▪ what I have done, was purely out of Kindness to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: D. Boast. Beatrice.
sp.p: I have consider'd on't, and I will own thee for my Wife, and as my Wife thou art a Lady, and know your State, and take the upper hand of your two 〈◊〉: 'tis some Revenge to see thee take place of those two proud Minxes.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Come, play away for the Dance.

div.stage: All the Company seat themselves, Beatrice takes place of all the Women.
` A Dance. Toby, in the habit of a Bearer, and 〈◊〉 3 Beares dance with the 4 Maids.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: So, Mr. Lovel and Daughter, I wish you much Joy together: the Match is of your own making; and when either of you repent it, you must blame your selves.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That Marriage can hardly know Repentance, in which both parties had their choice.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: My Lord, I intreat you, let my House have the Honour to treat you to night.

sp.speaker: D. Boast.
sp.p: I embrace your Kindness: give me your Hand, now no more Beatrice, but my Lady, we will suddainly down to my Country-House, and there fix our selves, and visit London but seldom; the Town is not a place for Wives to live in, that bring no Portions.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I shall like a Country-life very well, if I have but the Honour of your Lordships good Company; and, I doubt not, but in few years to raise a Portion out of my good Huswifery.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Come, I'le lead you the way to a better Room, Mr. Careless, Ladies, and all, pray follow.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Uncle, Slife, you are for rising from Table before Dinner's done, the third Course is yet to come up.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Pray, lead on, Sir; I beseech you, lead on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Come, come, Careless, ne're halt before a Cripple.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Good Madam, you are sharp set, I dare not trust my self with you, unless they will all stay.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: Niece, what say you to me?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It come just now in my mind, that I have lost my Bed-fellow; and now my Cousin is gon, I know not what I shall do; for, I vow, I dare not lie alone.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: O no, 'tis dangerous, for after seeing Marriages and new Married folks put to bed together, as strange dreams and fancies will be apt to run in your mind, as after seeing bloody Executions and dead people at the Gallows: and who knows what a taking you may be in i'th' night, and what strange fits you may have.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Aye, some e'ne rave upon the like occasions, and bite, and gnaw, and tear the very sheets in pieces.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: O Madam, aye so they do.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well Uncle, you may go, I'le e'ne send for one of the Neighbours Daughters from the next door to lye with me.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: O Madam, 'tis a hundred to one, but she may fall into the same fits and fancies too, and that will be more dangerous still, to have two mad folks in a bed, and neither able to allay the others fury.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: O Sir, do you begin to come about, wou'd you beat off others, that you may be my Bed-fellow your self? I perceive that you are for having a Wife.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I for a Wife?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nay, ●ay, 'tis so, ne'r deny't. Well Sir, give me your hand, rather then lye alone to night, I'le do any thing.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I knew 'twould come to this.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: ● w'll be your Wife, and since I can't have a Gallant before Marriage, I'le do like other Wives, and have one after; and, now I think on't too, a Husband is very necessary, if it is only to save the trouble of being ask'd questions o're and o're, as who's the Father, who go it? and besides, what Children the Gallant gets, the Husband must keep.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I can be even with you there, for you can bring me none to keep, but what are your own at least; and if you expect I should be Father to all your Children, I expect you should be a Nurse to all mine, and I may have 'um brought home to me on all sides, from twenty several women; for I intend to be a great getter and Father of many.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well, I have but this thing more to say to you; whosoever I choose for my Gallant, you are not to quarrel, or call out with him, but on the contrary, to make him your particular intimate Friend, to be always inviting him home to Dinner, and the like.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: And also, whosoever I like for a Mistress, be the Maid, Wife, or Widdow, you are to get acquainted with her, to Visit her often, to speaking my praise, and tell my good qualities, to commend my abilities; and in fine, to use the utmost of your power to bring us together, gain us opportunity, and if need be, to watch at the Stair-head, and in case of necessity, to hold the door.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: In Company, you shall never call me Wife, or Dear, or Sweet-hear●, but Madam.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: In Company you shall never call me Husband, or by my Christian Name, but Mr. Careless.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: In none of these particulars will I ever offend Mr. Careless.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: In none of these particulars will I ever offend you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: This 'tis for Folks to meet that understand themselves; Marriage with these Circumstances▪ I like well enough, and must certainly be very pleasant and delightful.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Sir, I beg your pardon, for detayning you and the Company so long; but you'l excuse it, being a business of concern; and each party ought to understand the other before they set their Hands and Seals to the Engagement.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Uncle, pray con o're the Articles, for you are to be summon'd for a Witness upon occasion.

sp.speaker: Muchw.
sp.p: It is like to be a fine Marriage.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes, if it go on according to Agreement.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You shall see our Marriage (which you think is clapt up out of a frollick) go on more chearfully than yours, made out of stark Love and desperate Affection; we, like two Birds (though we Roost together at Night) will have our freedom all Day, and flie Ch●ripping about, whil'st you like two Domestick Animals, ti'de too close together in a string, shall still be snarling and biting one another.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And we have the trouble every now and than to part you; mark the event on't.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Mrs. Clap. and Mrs. Breedw. you must not think you have quite lost me, because I am Married, and so pray tell the rest of my Acquaintance; I am enter'd into Matrimony, but not in to Bondage.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: He has, as it were but one Mistress the more: L ead away Uncle.
sp.l: Whilst other Wives, and Husbands, Scold and Rant,
We two will live like Mistress and Gallant.

lg.l: GAllants, 'tis fear'd, after our last Loud Play,
You will be Deaf to all Low Wit can say.
Light'ning, Machine and Noyse your Favourites are.
Those Murdering Playes, the Stage's Men of War,
Drive all before 'um, like an English Fleet:
All's Prize that in their Thunders-reach they meet;
Their mighty First-Rate Strength so great appears;
We Younger Actors seem but Privateers:
And like true Pickroons, this time we choose;
Where the Great Ships lye by, the Capers Cruze.
Yet we engage with full as much Devotion,
Tho' with less Hope, and far less Execution.
How e're we ' Adventurers so little Stake,
'Tis all clear Profit whatsoe're we Take;
Whil'st they from the large Booty they had got,
Pay Tribute to the Force that Set them out:
As if Gay Playes, like Navies, had this Check,
In a Rich Prize to Plunder but one Deck.
Yet their Fame's greater, tho' their Gain be less,
You kindly say, they merited Success.
Their Triumphs so much above ours prevail,
You'l own, they Won your Money, which we steal.
They Conquer a more Honourable way;
Their Spoyls are Victory, and ours but Prey.
Now has our Damn'd dull Epilogue ill us'd you;
I'me sure, it has not pleas'd; that is, abus'd you.
— But that small Fault to Day
May be excus'd, we've don't enough inth ' Play.
